2021-08-10 18:22:19+02:00

Victoria 3 | Monthly Update #2 | August | Paradox Interactive Forums

Welcome to our second Monthly Update video for Victoria 3! This month we will be looking into the contents of July’s Dev Diaries. Enjoy! Smile :)

​

OCR: Landowners Government Suppress Promote Join Remove Ideologies Clout Traits 28.8% Approval Neutral (+4) Leader Friedrich August von Gise Population 9.7K 5.86K Aristocrats 390K Pol.Str Prosperous (26.9) 3.43K Clergymen 25.9K Pol.Str Middling (16.5)

OCR: State Svealand Culture Swedish Religion Protestant Status Growth +157 Literacy 90.0% Radicals Loyalists Interest Group Wealth This Pop Interest Group is Industrialists Standard Of Living Secure 20 Interest Group Membership 756 Pops are part of the Industrialists (Attraction: 59%) Net Inc. {+0.29K 402 Pops are part of the Petite Bourgeoisie (Attraction: 25%) 165 Pops are part of the Intelligentsia (Attraction: 10%} Primary IG 58 Pops are part of the Church of Sweden (Attraction: 4%) Pol: Str 20.6K 119 Pops are Politically Inactive and do not support any Interest Group 3.49K Pops are Disenfranchised Dependents that cannot participate in politics Seo Banic" Prus sia Primary

OCR: Input Goods Shortage in Food Industries There is only enough Sell Orders for Sugar available in Bohemia to satisfy 19.14% of the Orders, resulting in an penalty on all outputs for this Building: Current penalty is 23% and will change over time towards the target penalty of 23%_ At least 25% of Buy Orders for Sugar must be satisfied to avoid an output penalty. You can resolve the shortages by increasing the number of Sell Orders for Sugar in Austrian Market This can be done by either producing more Sugar; improving Infrastructure in States with low Market Access producing it, setting up Trade Route to get it from another Market. OCR: WIP Ljubljana PH Qualifications Game Concept Pops develop the qualifications necessary to become different Pop Types over time. If their current attributes match those of the poptype, ifthey currently in a related field; will develop qualifications sooner. Literacy, Wealth; and Discrimination are common deciding factors. Victoria 3 | Monthly Update #4 | October | Paradox Interactive Forums

Time for another splendid Monthly Update Video from the Victoria 3 team! In this video, we are covering topics that relate to internal politics.

Topics covered, in order by time stamps:

00:23 - Standard of Living

04:15 - Political Movements

07:12 - Slavery

10:31 - States

12:54 - Migration

For the screenshots used in the video, please see the files attached to this post!

OCR: WIP ARAGON State Overview Buildings Information Unincorporated State Click to incorporate Aragon Cost: 57.2 T/Bureaucracy An Unincorporated State is controlled by Country but is considered territorial holding or frontier not formally accepted as a part ofthe country proper. Pops who live here are disenfranchised and do not contribute much Political Strength to their Interest Groups An Unincorporated State can be turned into an Incorporated State, which will it under the direct French Market management of the Country central authority. put

Victoria 3 | Monthly Update #5 | November | Paradox Interactive Forums

Salutations, Victorians, and welcome to another Monthly Update video from the Victoria 3 team! In this month’s video, we are delving deep into Diplomacy.

00:26 - Rank and Prestige

02:10 - Relations, Infamy, and Interests

05:43 - Diplomatic Actions

09:01 - Diplomatic Plays

For the screenshots used in the video, please see the files attached to this post!

2021-12-08 17:35:01+01:00

Wizzington commented on Twitter Teasers Thread

MylesSCP said:

It's not too important, but I hope Universities employ more than just Academics to teach. Laborers should also be employed to represent janitors and handymen for maintance, and maybe some Bureaucrats to represent administrators.

They employ Academics, Clerks and Laborers at the moment IIRC.

2022-01-25 16:25:56+01:00

Wizzington commented on Twitter Teasers Thread

Thure said:

So Generals can be political leaders too. I thought the said this wasn't possible in the DD about generals? Seems like they changed it than, which is good.

It was always something we wanted to do, and now we did it.

2022-03-01 23:17:25+01:00

lachek commented on Twitter Teasers Thread

TheBeautifulVoid said:

In software development and some other fields, PDT can mean paid development time.

Ah, the tech industry and its TLA's (Three Letter Acronyms) Big Grin :D PDT at Paradox stands for "Personal Development Time", which in practice means a day per month we can work on a pet project - for our own game, another team's game, tools to make our lives easier, a personal prototype, or whatever. Often these are just throwaway projects or proof-of-concepts, occasionally they make it into the games.

So with @Wizzington 's blessing I decided this was a good opportunity for me to test out the boundaries of what Game Rules could be used for, and make some enhancements to make Production Method (even) more flexible - including a test for state religion.

So this particular feature really didn't take away from any planned development, nor will it impact QA resources in any meaningful way. Monuments with their unique effects are cool (imo) but they don't impact the game balance to such an extent that we need to do continuous regression testing with different Game Rule permutations.

2022-03-22 17:38:54+01:00

Wizzington commented on Twitter Teasers Thread

MfgLuckbot said:

Hmm does that mean if we don't employ clergy they will cease to exist in our nation or are there (private) church service buildings as well where they work their normal priest duties?

2022-02-05 08:06:38+01:00

PDJR_Alastorn commented on AAR Thread

shoebird said:

Uhm, so his GDP grew a 50% due to inflation? Did I get it right? Is this because GDP is nominal and not ppp? I wonder if it will be possible to use GDP (ppp). I also wonder what is the price for such inflation.

My GDP did not grow to inflation per say - its more that I am speculating heavily in industries as the first producer - steel and locomotives. Knowing this I am saying my current evaluation is inflated higher than it should be.

Because of this I am reaping the rewards of being the first main producer: high prices in a market that wants these goods but once the AI starts upping its production as well, my profits will diminish and the bubble will burst... unless I move on to the next industrial good before that.

I have been able to get away with this for longer that usual becauase turmoil at home in Germany and across the world is making it where the AI is having trouble establishing more complex industries.

My GDP is based on the value of the goods I am producing, so I know the value of my goods are inflated due to such and would expect that GDP will not grow as quickly in the future because all growth will be offset by the decrease in these values as the AI catches up.

2022-02-05 16:49:19+01:00

PDJR_Alastorn commented on AAR Thread

shoebird said:

I’m a bit ignorant on economics, but why is not inflation? Because is not generalized to all goods?

In any case, wouldn’t it be more fair to calculate the GDP ppp to compare different economies (or economies in different markets)?

Its just an attempt to keep terms clearer in understanding - inflation is a term that is known to be in discussion of monetary policy and the valueation of money comparatively to itself over time. It is generally a term that is utilized to describe the movement of a group of goods, not a singular one.

While if a goods price is high due to having more demand than supply, it is certainly "inflated" but that is not "inflation" it may seem pedantic but its ultimately just there to try and avoid confusion, so we don't get comments that are thinking its because we are utilizing monetary levels of policy when in fact its fiscal - ie the actual purchasing of goods and services, not the adjustment of the money supply.

2022-02-05 17:00:11+01:00

PDJR_Alastorn commented on AAR Thread

Purchasing Power Parity would also not be the best statistic to utilizefor GDP measurement because its not meant to measure GDP, its meant to measure relative standard of living due to national labor markets and exchange rate manipulation by governments.

Its trying to clear the confusion of our modern world with multiple national currencies and say what the exchange rate means to the consumer. This statistic would be irrelvant to be put in V3 at the moment because we do not have any significant monetary policy levers and it is also (partially) abstracted in our standard of living statistics for each nation.

Standard of living for V3 is basically saying - for this countries GDP - this is what it means for the economic classes, which while not a 1:1 to PPP its a reasonable historical variant.

2022-02-05 17:05:17+01:00

PDJR_Alastorn commented on AAR Thread

shoebird said:

It is true that people tend to link inflation only with monetary policy so I understand that you want to make it clear that there’s no monetary policy in the game. But inflation can be also caused by high prices of certain key goods and services, or am I wrong with this? For istance, isn’t that what is happening in Europe due to high prices of energy right now?

This led me to a question. Can high prices of coal or electricity in Vic 3 have an “inflationary” effect?

Yes, it would qualify as "supply-shock" or "cost-push" inflation if you felt that using the word inflation was needed. Normally to avoid confusion I just say "increase in prices" as its when you see the relative increase in prices in one or multiple goods eat away at a standard of living. Its not normally known in most parlence as inflation - that one goes to money supply based inflation.

We saw the high prices of coal literally bring down my Lubeck economy for a few years.

2022-02-05 17:22:59+01:00

PDJR_Alastorn commented on AAR Thread

Revolution 11 said:

Inflation is simply a general and progressive rise of prices. There is no requirement that inflation is due to money supply although that is a factor, one of many. It is possible for the money supply to increase and inflation to not happen at all. It is also possible for the money supply to not change at all and inflation to occur on a massive scale.

Please before you start an "actually" comment read the previous comments where I explain that inflation can be both monetary and fiscal (as in supply shocks) but due to the number of conversations where we have talked about inflation solely in terms of monetary policy and the predominance of understanding inflation in that terms that I like to make it clearer when I draw the distinction.

Thank you. You're not wrong, you're technically correct, the best kind I can tell you, but its not helping the conversation.

2022-02-05 17:39:56+01:00

PDJR_Alastorn commented on AAR Thread

shoebird said:

I see, I thought that ppp had also into account the differences in local prices. For instance let’s say that we have country A and country B. In country A a car cost 20k and in country B 25k, both in the same currency. If country A produces 2 M cars and country B 1.7M cars, the GDP due to car production will be 40000M for country A and 42500M for country B. But a car is a car and country B produces less cars, should it have more GDP due to cars?

This makes me think. The day has come and I’m playing Vic 3. I am producing 100k furnitures that are sold at 100 each amounting to a “furniture” GDP of 10M My industries can be profitable with a lower price and I could import more furniture to improve SOL. So I import it and prices reduce to 80. Now my GDP is reduced by 2M even if my pops are richer. Is that correct? It feels a bit strange to me.

In any case thank for your replies. I’m probably not alone if I say that this responses by devs are highly appreciated, specially in Saturday. Thank you very much.

I feel like you are attempting to be a bit too reductive in this example and look at this statically, when there are a few dynamics thatwould result that can make the change.

While your lowered prices of goods would mean that the standard of living of your pops would go up - there is no guarantee it would stay up. As you have lowered the selling price of your domestic factories (in this scenario) and they may adjust wages of your domestic market relative to this, which will as a result mean they have a lower purchasing power and see their standard of living drop despite prices having dropped (it is entirely dependent upon the relative elasticity of their consumption basket of goods relative to the elasticity of the goods produced that supply their income).

This is the problem with single industry examples, your workforce is locked into this industry here and thus the attempts to create clarity create unknowns.

If you could import furniture at a lower cost than you can domestically produce it, your standard of living would go up assuming you could move that part of your labor force that is out of the job into profitable industires equal or or greater than the furniture factories. This is the zero-sumness of trade with comparative advantage. It can sometimes be hard to wrap one's head around because it necessitates a lot of moving parts but it also assumes things like the flexibility of our economy.

If you could not move your labor force after importing cheaper furniture, your SOL would quickly start dropping to reflect your lesser GDP.

2022-05-03 21:23:02+02:00

Wizzington commented on AAR Thread

Praetorian44 said:

I keep seeing people post this on the forums, but I've never been able to find a post where the developers actually say this. Do you have a link to a developer stating this? Because I don't think Wiz was playing on some sort of faster build. It was even asked in the AAR why he was able to do everything so fast, and Wiz stated something along the lines that everything happens faster than expected in Vicky 3 due to the four ticks per day. If he was playing on a special build where everything was made quicker, then this would have been the perfect time for him to state this, but he did not. So this is just my opinion, based on hardly any evidence, but I think the AARs have been played on a build without anything sped up, and then fans are making up the "faster build" to explain why everything is so quick and easy to do. We all might be quite surprised when the game releases if this is just misinformation everyone is spreading.

This is a thing. It's not that we have a special speeded up build, it's that we've avoided doing too much balancing on pacing because faster pacing makes it easier to test and develop features up until late in development.

2022-03-07 20:21:17+01:00

Wizzington commented on Wait, so we can barely give any order to our generals because we're playing as a "nation", so we're well above that, but...

There really isn't a contradiction here. Playing as the 'spirit of the nation' doesn't mean that the player necessarily should have, or should not have control of any one specific aspect of their country. All it means is that we are not designing the game with the idea that the player is any one specific actor or group of actors within the nation and thus should be restricted to what they would be able to control. What we let the player control and not control is thus entirely governed by what we feel best fits the game's design and makes for the best (in our view) overall gameplay. The reason you can't directly control your armies has nothing to do with playing as the spirit of the nation and everything to do with our design goals for the military system.

2022-03-21 09:09:29+01:00

DebbieElla commented on Wait, so we can barely give any order to our generals because we're playing as a "nation", so we're well above that, but...

Thread moderated. Stay on topic, stay kind.

Revols or Secessions are different now as they trigger a special kind of Diplomatic Play, allowing an international response on either side. Suppressing German socialists by crushing them will be risky as other powers might intervene on their side. But more on that in a future dev diary Smile :)

2021-12-26 15:28:23+01:00

Wizzington commented on Why Congress Poland should be on the map in 1836... in about 26000 characters

Al-Khalidi said:

It depends for some it would be fun as we can see, but for some it definitely wouldn't. For me it would ruin big part of fun. I for example want to play Ottoman Empire and have a powerful russia as adversary - russia it was, with powerful army, oppressing minorities. Russia with polish puppet would be immersion breaking - not historical, weaker than really was, etc.

If someone really wishes to play Poland, why not release puppet as russia?

Let's add another argument here which I saw in someone's comment somewhere else: if Poland - historically at that time just a region with some autonomy - can be a puppet, then a puppet is not the proper thing for for example Tunis - a state with ruler, army, subject of Ottoman sultan. Then Tunis should be a protectorate - but then Serbia, a state with higher autonomy than Tunis, should be a yet different type of subject that currently doesn't exist.

Making Poland playable at the game start would require a special new type of subject that is basically incapable of doing anything. I don't see point in that.

Comparison to Finland, even if it made sense, is problematic in context of other states that are puppets in game, such as Tunis, which had far far far more autonomy than Poland die to reasons described above.

Tunis is a Protectorate - the most independent type of subject. I think they were incorrectly set as a Puppet at some point previously though.

2022-01-09 12:02:17+01:00

KaiserJohan commented on Electricity is, well, weird.

CaptinObvious said:

This definitely feels like "Yes, but we ran out of time/budget to do before release"

It working like a service kinda doesn't work, since there was a whole debate in this period about AC vs DC (Nikola vs Edison) and one of the main reasons we went with AC is that AC can be easily stepped-up and stepped-down (extreme oversimplification)...but look, I studied a lot of electrical stuff in uni, and this is me over-nerding out about electricity

Short answer: electricity would genuinely need it's own mechanics

I'd like a grid system, where you can build a continent-spanning super monstrosity...but that's too much detail

Expanding on Electricity is a cool expansion idea! As you say we have to pick-and-choose where to put our effort in; we can't do everything for release Smile :)

2022-01-14 17:59:35+01:00

Wizzington commented on Concern over the AI

As has been said a number of times, the AI is currently in a relatively early stage with a lot of iteration and balancing TBD. Normally we wouldn't really show off the game with an alpha AI but the AARs are a bit of an exception. The plan is certainly not for the world to be this chaotic in the release version.

2022-01-14 01:40:53+01:00

KaiserJohan commented on Pie Charts

captain beaver said:

YESTERDAY, January 12 2022, a date which will live in infamy, pie charts were suddenly and deliberately removed by programmers and UX designers of Paradox.

The pie chart interest group was at peace with that company and, at the solicitation of Paradox, was still in conversation with its lead developers looking toward the maintenance of pie charts in the UI. Indeed, one hour after Paradox UX designers had commenced disparaging pie charts in the developer diary, the Paradox Community Ambassador and his colleague delivered to our interest group leader Darkath a formal reply to a recent pie chart demonstration of superiority. And while this reply stated that it seemed useless to continue the existing negotiations, it contained no threat or hint of removal or of being downgraded to a secondary option.

It will be recorded that the distance of internet wires from Sweden makes it obvious that the attack was deliberately planned many days or even weeks ago. During the intervening time, the Paradox development team has deliberately sought to deceive the pie charts interest group by false statements and expressions of hope for continued primacy in the UI.

The attack yesterday on pie charts has caused severe damage to our interest group’s intention to buy the game. I regret to tell you that very many pie charts supporters have been lost. In addition pie charts supporters have been reported disparaged on the forums by a hitherto unknown fifth column of treemapping supporters.

Paradox has, therefore, undertaken a surprise offensive extending throughout the UI. The facts of yesterday and today speak for themselves. The pie charts interest group has already formed its opinions and well understand the implications to the very life and safety of our charts.

As Commander in Chief of pie charts, I have directed that all measures be taken for our defense.

But always will our whole Pie remember the character of the onslaught against us.

No matter how long it may take us to overcome this premeditated removal from the UI, pie charts in their righteous might will win through to absolute supremacy.

I believe that I interpret the will of the interest group when I assert that we will not only defend pie charts to the uttermost but will make it very certain that this form of treachery shall never again endanger us.

Hostilities exist. There is no blinking at the fact that our charts, our way of conveying information, and our graphical distinctiveness are in grave danger.

With confidence in our charts with the unbounding determination of easily read information they convey, we will gain the inevitable triumph so help us Pie.

I ask that the assembled members of our interest group declare that since the unprovoked and dastardly sneak attack by Paradox on Wednesday, January 12, 2022, a state of war has existed between pie charts and Paradox

WE, by the grace of Johan, Kaiser of Sweden, seated on the throne occupied by the same dynasty from time immemorial, enjoin upon ye, Our loyal and brave fans:

We hereby declare War on pie charts. The programmers and UX designers of Our Team shall do their utmost in prosecuting the war. Our public servants of various departments shall perform faithfully and diligently their respective duties; the entire team with a united will shall mobilize their total strength so that nothing will miscarry in the attainment of Our war aims.

[ ... absurdly long paragraph ... ]

The hallowed spirits of Our Imperial Ancestors guarding Us from above, We rely upon the loyalty and courage of Our fans in Our confident expectation that the task bequeathed by Our forefathers will be carried forward and that the sources of evil will be speedily eradicated and an enduring peace immutably established in our forums, preserving thereby the glory of Victoria 3.

In witness whereof, we have hereunto set Our hand and caused the Grand Seal of the Empire to be affixed at the Imperial Palace, Stockholm, this fourtenth day of the 1st month of the 2022 year, corresponding to the 2,602nd year from the accession to the throne of Emperor Johan.​

(yes this is obviously a joke, we love charts & graphs Big Grin :D)

2022-01-10 15:20:02+01:00

KaiserJohan commented on Steel & Steel Production in Vicky3

Steel is used in more advanced production methods in your construction camps. Cheap steel means you can afford to build more and faster which is nice.

2022-01-04 08:32:58+01:00

KaiserJohan commented on Four ticks per day

Some game mechanics run on partial ticks such as Battle rounds. Also some weekly calculations are spread out over all ticks in the week.

2021-12-20 12:07:37+01:00

Wizzington commented on Spain is being represented much poorer than it was in real history (countries GDP per capita comparison between the game and real historical data)

Yeah, this is on the todolist to revise. We're not aiming for exact parity with history in terms of GDP (because our economic simulation is not an exact match to history either) but Spain is clearly too underdeveloped, even accounting for the fact that their colonial subjects' economies aren't included in their GDP in-game.

2021-12-20 13:34:46+01:00

Wizzington commented on Spain is being represented much poorer than it was in real history (countries GDP per capita comparison between the game and real historical data)

The Goldfinch said:

Speaking about revisions, is it entirely accurate that at the game start Prussia and Austria combined still have smaller GDP than France?

One thing that should be noted is that Pops in subsistence counts very little for GDP, less than they should if we were trying to be strictly realistic. I do think Austria might be too underdeveloped, but part of this is game balance too - trying to ensure that Austria doesn't just stomp on Prussia's face every single game, etc.

2021-12-21 15:56:40+01:00

Wizzington commented on Spain is being represented much poorer than it was in real history (countries GDP per capita comparison between the game and real historical data)

The GDP data shouldn't be treated as gospel or that the game is broken if countries don't match the data either directly or relatively, but it is a useful indicator of relative level of development at the start of the game, so we're certainly not going to ignore it entirely either. I think this thread made some fair points (and it was already on my todolist to buff Spain and probably also Austria a bit) backed by data. As with everything we use as a source and reference when building our games, we use the source material in our decision-making but ultimately, we're making a game and the most important part of the history setup is the historical plausibility of the outcomes, not that the numbers align absolutely perfectly. However, if we can make those numbers a bit more historical (as best we can get it with the sources available) without the result being outweighted by less believable outcomes, I see no reason not to do so.

2021-12-18 13:06:28+01:00

Wizzington commented on Africa tribe playable?And what about the formable nations?

Creamu said:

The Ashanti Empire being decentralized is one of the most puzzling things about Africa this map.

Oversight on my part. I think they should be playable but I haven't gotten around to changing it yet.

2021-12-20 13:44:57+01:00

Wizzington commented on Africa tribe playable?And what about the formable nations?

ikki said:

Mybe due to the economic model of waging war to capture slaves and selling slaves for more guns resulting in a bloodbath of terror and horror worst since mongols... and have this as a kind of atrocitymeter vs antislavery sentiments leading to one of the growing pressures for a scramble for africa.

If committing atrocities was the criteria for being decentralized, there'd be a lot of the world up for grabs, most definitely including the British Isles.

2021-12-18 14:26:29+01:00

Wizzington commented on Fantasy - not so fantasy restorations/formations and why should they be included

By this point, the title of Caliph had sort of lost most of its meaning and become more of a prestige title claimed by a whole bunch of different states to try and gain religious legitimacy, so I really don't think having it as a tag makes too much sense in the 19th century. It'd have to be a 'silly' tag, or represented through for instance a decision you take to 'restore' the title after unifying a large chunk of the Islamic world.

2021-12-18 14:30:03+01:00

Wizzington commented on Fantasy - not so fantasy restorations/formations and why should they be included

Al-Khalidi said:

Might not be best for tag indeed. But those fundamentalist ideas about looking into islamic past were actually ON RISE. What would then happen to islamic theocracies, what would they be called?

I don't see an issue with one or several Islamic theocracies calling themselves a caliphate, my point was more about the idea of The Caliphate as a single polity.

2021-12-18 13:24:18+01:00

Wizzington commented on Will Beer Be a Good?

Beer is currently consolidated into the broader Liquor good. As a lover of beer (especially German stuff, bring on the Rauchbier) myself, I think it would be neat to see it as a good but only if we can find a meaningful enough way to distinguish it from liquor either in production or consumption.

2021-12-18 13:56:11+01:00

Wizzington commented on Will Beer Be a Good?

BotherMe said:

Isn’t the new obsession mechanic a good reason to have both beer and liquor as goods? Vodka belt vs beer belt. Russian pops may get an obsession with liquor and the German pops with beer.

I wouldn't say it's enough to warrant a new good, no. The most compelling reason would be some sort of interesting difference in how beer is produced versus liquor, since they'd probably end up in the same pop need.

2021-12-18 14:22:09+01:00

Wizzington commented on Will Beer Be a Good?

I mean, that's precisely the kind of meaningful production difference I'm talking about, where producing liquor is sugar-intensive while beer is grain-intensive (in this case grain would take the role of hops, unless we want to add hops as a good but that seems a little too hyper-specific). That's of course something of a simplification of reality (not all liquor is produced the same way after all), but reflective enough of reality that I'd consider implementing it. That doesn't mean I'm promising a beer good for release, but I'll actively consider it now.

2021-12-15 22:59:15+01:00

Wizzington commented on Can Mexico conquer US?

It really depends on the context here, here's how I would want it to play out:

Can a Mexico that has secured strong allies like Great Britain defeat the US? Sure, that's doable, though they probably shouldn't want to back any Mexican attempts to annex the US core states.

Can Mexico beat back the US in the early game? Shouldn't be impossible, though the US is stronger on the defense than the offense, so conquering them should be a lot harder.

Can a mid-game Mexico with no allies, little industrial development and a relatively backwards army defeat a historical US with a larger, more advanced army? Probably not, maybe if they have an absolutely brilliant general and the US has terrible commanders.

Can an industrialized Mexico that has kept up with the times and built up its military go defeat the US alone? Possibly, if the US hasn't built up its army enough or Mexico's economy has caught up that of the US (perhaps through becoming the #1 migrant magnet in the new world) over the course of the decades.

PDX_Maciej commented on can we have a devclash when the game is ready to be showed off to us?

2021-11-16 22:19:16+01:00

lachek commented on Victoria 3 | Monthly Update #5 | November

InsidiousMage said:

Question for the devs - Can diplomatic plays end in a negotiated settlement or can they only end in war or with one side backing down?

InsidiousMage said:

Yeah, I knew that could happen in a war but the devs have always made it sound like a diplo play has to end in war or backing down, which would be strange. Hopefully they can it's covered when peace settlements.

A Diplomatic Play is not to be thought of as a negotiation between two sides to come to a mutually satisfactory resolution. It is best thought of as a demand and implied threat by one side, which they at least pretend is totally legitimate - much like a Casus Belli / War Justification.

The other side can add demands of their own, again not to negotiate an agreement, but to up the stakes. The Diplomatic Play can only escalate, never de-escalate, much like how in poker nobody can take their ante back if they also agree another player may return theirs.

So no, a Diplomatic Play cannot end in a negotiated agreement where both sides walk away having won some/lost some. Either one side submit to the other's demand, or this chest-puffing leads to an actual conflict with both greater risks and greater rewards. That conflict can end in a compromise agreement, but that's because all pretense that the claimant was fully justified in their demands is now gone and participants are bargaining with their lives.

2021-11-16 23:14:38+01:00

lachek commented on Victoria 3 | Monthly Update #5 | November

InsidiousMage said:

Thanks for the info. Follow up question - can to powers negotiate for things they can get through war without having to go to war to get it? For example, if I want province X can I pay the nation that owns that province for it? Of offer them market access and favorable trade deals? Or offer territory in exchange?

These sorts of transactional tit-for-tat deals are not part of our diplomatic system repertoire, no. Certain effects (e.g. I'll trade you 10% of my income for 10% of your Influence, or whatever) could theoretically be modeled using bilateral Pacts and one might argue that e.g. Subject pacts are all about trading autonomy for protection and economic benefits. But freeform diplomatic negotiations that you might see in Stellaris or Civ, where you put some stuff of yours in a bucket and asks for a similarly-valued bucket of stuff in return, is not modeled for a couple of reasons: 1, it's very gamey and often pretty unrealistic in practice (100 barrels of oil per week plus a suitcase with £645k in unmarked bills in exchange for a research pact and the entire state of Loire seems to have equal value, sign on the dotted line please!) and 2, it's very difficult to balance to make it worth your while while not also being extremely exploitable.

2021-12-05 23:56:08+01:00

lachek commented on Victoria 3 | Monthly Update #5 | November

Testeria said:

So no buying of Alaska in CK3? We need war for that?

There are situations in which land can change hands outside of Diplomatic Plays and peace deals, which includes the Alaska Purchase. It just isn't dealt with through a diplomatic trade system, for the aforementioned reasons.

Ofaloaf commented on Some feedback points on the Africa map

2021-11-29 16:20:09+01:00

KaiserJohan commented on When a naval force lands

When naval invading you select the Admiral to escort the troops, a General to land with and the target State.

Any enemy admirals in the region may intercept you at sea causing a naval battle to take place. Even if they loose they will incur a combat penalty depending on damage done.

If you win the naval battle the landing proceeds and you get a beachhead battle which if you win will establish a new Front.

Hope this clears things up Big Grin :D

2021-11-30 14:16:18+01:00

KaiserJohan commented on When a naval force lands

Al-Khalidi said:

Thanks for these informations! What forces are found on the other (defending) side of the front? The ones enemy assigns to defend that region? Is it possible that there aren't any forces there and invading force just occupies the state?

I also wonder what happens if you allow enemy to land and THEN destroy their fleet, will the invading army be quickly forced to surrender because of lack of supply? What happens if the state we capture splits enemy force in two (like in Italy)? Ehh, so many questions related to invasions Big Grin :D

The defending side can use one General on Standby from a HQ in that region and/or reserve units. If there are no forces present it's auto-success (i.e "battle" is won immediately). The General is subject to any normal supply rules once Front is established (reserved for future DD's) Smile :)

2021-11-21 17:47:10+01:00

Wizzington commented on GDP per Capita

GDP per Capita is shown in the GDP tooltip for a country.

2021-08-26 19:18:52+02:00

Wizzington commented on Why is Egypt independent?

Stein14 said:

Only between 1831 and 1840 Egypt was not a subject of the Ottoman Empire but was more or less in open revolt. Only the intervention of the Europeans in 1840/41 forced Egypt to withdraw from Palistine and Syria and to recognize the sovereignty of the Ottoman Empire again. So the only one who needs a historian is you.

Yeah, in 1836 Egypt was very much a subject in name only, but there is content around the Oriental Crisis that can result in the historical outcome of Egypt becoming a subject again.

2021-11-19 12:46:05+01:00

2021-11-20 13:44:38+01:00

Wizzington commented on Dev diary #24 and puppets on the map

Froonk said:

I wonder if Serbia is independent in 1836 like Victoria 2? Serbia really should have same status as Moldovia in 1836.

Serbia is a Protectorate, same as Moldovia and Wallachia.

2021-11-16 13:33:32+01:00

lachek commented on Generals should draw their plans on the map

Ololorium said:

I really don't understand why the devs consider pausing/speed 5 is a problem to be solved though...

Because if we designed the game around the premise that if people are bored they can always turn to speed 5, or if people are overwhelmed they can always pause, this has two major and intertwined detrimental effects on the game:

  • the game's pacing is a very different experience in large countries compared to small countries, where even with full speed controls players of smaller countries might feel like they have too little agency while larger countries can be outright tedious to manage

  • asymmetric multiplayer (e.g. where one player is a large country and at war, while another player is a small country at peace) becomes either overwhelming for the first player or boring for the second

In my view, when a player changes their game speed this should ideally be a subjective decision based on personal playstyle, not a way to "skip the boring parts" or "pull the emergency brake". Ideally there should be no boring parts, and the game should never overwhelm you with so many decisions in such a short amount of time that you have to stop the train in its tracks to take a breath.

Ideally, that is. Of course we're not going to remove this functionality, because there are extenuating circumstances or just personal preference. Pause/FF gameplay is fine and it's your option if you want to play that way. We're just not going to force you to do that by designing the game so you have to.

2021-06-14 09:45:36+02:00

KaiserJohan commented on Victoria 3 Reading Club

ImperatorLJ said:

I know this is reading so far, but I'd also recommend a listen to Mike Duncan's "Revolutions" podcast. It covers many of the revolutions, such as 1848 and that Russian Revolution, that color this period, and he also gives a ton of background to the 19th and early 20th century in general.

This one is great, highly recommend! Smile :)

2021-11-07 08:33:58+01:00

lachek commented on Multiple currencies (dollars, pounds, thaler, yen) in games

rowdyyobbo said:

It looks like unit prices are measured in pounds in Vicky. This raises a question that is even more interesting if my impression is wrong. Note: I am not well schooled in economics, please be generous in your responses.

An arch simulationist would propose a model that included multiple currencies, with exchange rates, and other arcane horrors. Goods in a province would be priced in the local currency. Intercurrency trade would take exchange rate into account. National policies around local currency could be set, if the nation controls the currency.

The implementation of multiple currencies would likely be expensive in computation and AI and potential runaway exploits (some exploitation would be the point and resulting tension would be the point Smile :) ).

In your opinion would the addition of multiple currency domains be valuable ("fun" being loaded)?

Speaking from the perspective of a player, where I think multiple currencies would be fun is:

  • deciding to become a sovereign issuer so I can control my own monetary policy vs. deciding to adopt someone else's in exchange for simplicity and stability

  • deciding if/when to switch my currency from being backed by precious metals (hard money) to governmental assurances (fiat money)

  • modeling falling or rising trust in a fiat currency and the hyperinflation or stagflation that can result

  • benefiting from my currency being dominant in local or global international trade

  • getting to name my currency and seeing the use of my own currency symbol in the UI

From the perspective of a developer, having to actually deal with hundreds of currencies whose values float freely against each other and who each have unique market- and local prices for all 50+ goods would not be worth any of those things. I think it's probably possible to create some of the gameplay dynamics above through some level of abstraction though. Hopefully we'll be able to take a crack at it in the future, because it's genuinely something I'd love to see in play!

2021-11-07 21:30:25+01:00

lachek commented on Multiple currencies (dollars, pounds, thaler, yen) in games

Traum77 said:

As a non-developer forgive the stupid question but... is there any technological solution currently available to eventually hitting this kind of near-real world system? GPU-run calculations? Cloud server offloading?

Because honestly once you're in a fiat currency scenario, I could also see all sorts of financial levers being fun for players to play with. Ok, "fun" may only apply to a small subset of economics geeks, but it would be great to have the opportunity to adjust money supply, devalue your currency to make exports more attractive, and trying to expand your monetary union (EU style). I'm excited to play with the system we'll have for Vic3, but wondering what kind of enhancements we might see in the future.

So the main problems as I see it (note that I'm not a programmer by trade beyond what I need to know as a systems designer, so take this with a grain of salt) is actually not processing power as such, but rather player responsiveness, code complexity, and data size.

Heavy calculations can usually be dealt with using caching techniques and load distribution across multiple threads, frames, even ticks in some cases. But large datasets (like what you might get by introducing a hundred-fold increase in the basic unit of the economic system) means larger game states / save files, and this can impact performance exponentially. To reduce data size it's necessary to invent domain-specific ways to represent the data more optimally, which increases code complexity. Increased complexity in a highly interconnected game means a high risk of difficult to detect bugs. And all of these clever solutions must be transparent to a player: any change to the game state imposed by a human must have immediate effects in the UI, or the game starts feeling laggy and confusing.

Modern graphics cards overcome some of these limitations by having large amounts of extremely high-bandwidth RAM available to the GPU, which offers domain-specific ways to efficiently compute solutions to the precise problems it's designed to solve. Today this includes physics as well as graphics problems. So what we really need is to convince Nvidia and AMD to include econ-sim operations and a dedicated API to the next generation GPUs! Big Grin :D Until then I imagine more RAM on higher-bandwidth buses will help a bit, and more cores of course.

But the biggest gains are always found in better design- and software engineering solutions.

2021-11-12 10:08:50+01:00

Wizzington commented on Please reconsider the ban on demobilization in war.

This is something are actively discussing a lot. The problem with allowing demobilization is that it takes a lot of what's interesting about mobilization (the fact that you're committing to certain expenses and losses) and risks turning it into 'oh yeah, just mobilize everyone and demobilize if you don't need them' but it is admittedly potentially awkward to be stuck with a fully mobilized 1 million man army because you need to wait for the naval invasion of Cuba to complete, so we'll need to find a good middle way approach between these two problems.

2021-10-21 13:26:42+02:00

PDX_Maciej commented on Inaccuracies in South America

Thanks for your feedback, folks! We will see what can be done Smile :)

2021-11-13 18:27:37+01:00

lachek commented on While everyone is debating about wars, I have a more important question: "Is February 29 a thing in Vic3?"

So this is actually my personal white whale.

Leap years are not supported in the Clausewitz engine's time/date system. This system underlies all our games, so changing it would mean not just rewriting the time/date system itself but also making sure none of the other games suffer unfortunate side effects as a result.

I have personally spent several days of "personal project" time fruitlessly trying to find a solution to this.

One day. One day, I will have my Feb 29th.

2021-11-04 20:47:18+01:00

Wizzington commented on War: hit or miss?

Eruth said:

Wiz specifically said that wars are not predetermined by starting conditions.

With the caveat that it of course depends on the war - if a player Luxemburg with 5000 soldiers tries to stand alone against the German Empire with hundreds of thousands of soldiers on its border, fails to secure any help from other countries and still refuses to back down in the Diplomatic Play, there isn't really any realistic path to victory for them. But that's an extreme example and most wars shouldn't be like that, especially since backing down in Diplomatic Plays exist as a way to diplomatically resolve completely lopsided conflicts. The example I was replying to was the Carlist rebellion, where I definitely don't think it should just be predetermined that the Carlists lose.

2021-08-18 16:06:16+02:00

hagerhink commented on An argument for knowing less

I don't see us doing this for Victoria, for both gameplay, UX and debuggability reasons. That being said, what we are doing in some places is to label different numbers with a descriptive name in order to make things more flavourful and easier to grasp. For instance, a Standard of Living of 1 is labeled as "Starving (1)" and Dye with the Market Price of £60.0 is labeled as "Market Price: £60.0 (Very Expensive)". The numbers could easily be modded away.

2021-10-28 16:58:20+02:00

Wizzington commented on Is it Time to Abandon the Infamy Mechanic?

Something that's worth noting which I don't think I made clear enough in the Relations/Infamy dev diary is that countries aren't going to react uniformly to another country's Infamy - whether or not they will be concerned depends on whether that country is a credible threat to their interests. For example, a Sokoto that hasn't somehow established an Interest somewhere in South America isn't going to be bothered no matter how much infamy a landlocked Paraguay piles on.

2021-10-28 16:55:51+02:00

Wizzington commented on let us colonise the poles

You'll have to wait until the Hollow Earth expansion, since the poles are obviously the main gateways to the Inner World.

It is, yes! It's a bit blurry in this tooltip, we just updated this icon to a higher-res version and the detail level is a little too high to parse as a text icon now. Will be fixed!

2021-10-27 23:07:29+02:00

Wizzington commented on Twitter teaser 27.10.2021- diplomatic plays

On who supports who, AI logic in who to support is fairly primitive in current build and it's important to note that the AI is far from always going to take a side just because they can - even a country with a preference for a side is usually going to want a concrete reason to take up arms, especially if supporting the aggressor.

2021-10-17 12:19:28+02:00

KaiserJohan commented on how will MP handle?

Our networking code is much better than it was a decade ago. Newer games (CK3, Victoria3) uses a new networking layer in our engine.

Desyncs (OOS) is up to each game team to prevent. Our goal is of course zero desyncs on release Smile :)

2021-10-18 00:18:44+02:00

KaiserJohan commented on how will MP handle?

unmerged(498175) said:

I'm interested to know if paradox will actually try to make multiplayer viable, or if it will be an afterthought like in eu4?

Will there still be pop up events that DEMAND the player's immediate attention? I think the event system is bad overall, but it's especially bad in a real-time, no-pausing, in-the-middle-of-a-war multiplayer setting. Some events require some thought about which alternative to choose, some events are just unimportant spam events, and all events immediately remove players' control of e.g. armies and demand a response of some kind. This is fine for singleplayer, but you simply CANNOT HAVE THIS in a multiplayer game. It is hard to come up with worse game design than this. Ideally, get rid of the spam events, even for singleplayer, and implement some kind of event-queue that the player can check when they have free time.

Events will behave somewhat differently from the old PDS formula, stay tuned for the DD Smile :)

Will you make it possible to wage a multifront war without the main obstacle being that players are LITERALLY UNABLE to focus on several fronts at once? Fighting a multifront war against players in eu4, even if you by numbers outmatch them combined, is impossible. In a game about global empires, it must be possible to actually play as one effectively, and not constantly lose wars against inferior enemies solely because they out-micro you. There must be ways to delegate more to the AI. Eu4 fleet missions and vassal interactions is a good start, but this system must be improved.

I would argue this is one of the reasons why MP is exciting! Big Grin :D

The ability to assign armies to AI control in Imperator was really nice. It wasn't perfect but it's a great step up from EU4 imo.

2021-10-06 18:26:13+02:00

Wizzington commented on Osaka as the capital of Japan

City names and map in general are very much not final, so Osaka as capital of Japan isn't some firm design decision taken, we'll review it when we do our final pass on the map.

2021-10-07 10:46:10+02:00

Wizzington commented on Osaka as the capital of Japan

Razmorg said:

Would be fun to hear your workflow regarding this. Like is a lot of this early stuff generated or is it just placed by someone without much direction to be cleaned up later? I think a lot of people assume things only get done if there's specific design direction.

It usually starts with using legacy databases from earlier games, then a first-pass implementation that is just based on getting something into the game even if it's not accurate, followed by repeated iteration passes. Those red WIP we put on everything really do in fact mean WIP, as it's better for us to have a fully populated database that contains a ton of errors we can work on later than to have a quarter-populated but perfect one.

2021-10-08 23:37:15+02:00

KaiserJohan commented on Some goods being harder to make?

pheonicia said:

I think you have it backwards. It's not if you're a powerful nation you can make these goods, but rather whether you can make these goods that makes you a powerful nation. Access to an educated populace and precursor materials is what lets you make advanced goods.

Also the demand in your markets. Making automobiles when your population is struggling with basic sustenance means your factory will go bankrupt since noone can afford to buy them. Only after your pops standard of living has increased will they start demanding more advanced goods.

You could however choose to be part of another nations market in which there might be demand for said automobiles.

2021-10-06 18:18:50+02:00

Wizzington commented on There should be a conditional support in diplomatic plays

This is absolutely going to be a thing, though you'll have to wait a few weeks for the details.

2021-09-14 19:53:06+02:00

The Goldfinch said:

Screenshots are based on several campaigns - most of them were captured between years 1836 and 1869. Smile :)

2021-09-14 19:56:33+02:00

PDJR_Alastorn commented on Victoria 3 | Monthly Update #3 | September

Kompetan said:

2021-09-14 20:15:46+02:00

lachek commented on Victoria 3 | Monthly Update #3 | September

EntropyAvatar said:

These are work in progress numbers, but not the numbers I expected...

Yes, these are work in progress numbers, we want to try to tighten these up a bit before release to increase the range of impact possible. At this point in development it's generally good to not set these too aggressively though - the economic engine underpins everything and the more extreme it can become the more severe the impact on the rest of the game. My plan is to tune these to be as harsh as possible without breaking the game. The impact of even small changes is greater than one would expect, since building expenses and revenues are both based on goods and the wages they're able to pay affect the Pop consumption and thereby demand for goods and thereby goods prices, etc etc.

2021-09-14 20:16:59+02:00

lachek commented on Victoria 3 | Monthly Update #3 | September

hjarg said:

But this begs the question- is there also a possibility to move goods by ships between say Palermo and Naples, if both have ports? Or are you doomed to land-based infrastructure alone when the provinces are connected by direct landline to the capital?

Yes Smile :)

2021-09-14 20:17:00+02:00

Ofaloaf commented on Victoria 3 | Monthly Update #3 | September

BrytonJSwan said:

Doing like 20 backflips in a row involuntarily from the sheer joy of looking at a bunch of images of maps

Edit: Wait, hold on, obligatory complaint about a map detail I don't like, it seems like British Columbia and Oregon Territory are split away into their own nation which I assume is maybe the Columbia Department, owned by the North West Company. The only issue is that the North West Company and the Husdons Bay Company (which I assume is the big blob taking up most of central Canada) were merged by the British Government in 1821, so by the start date they should be one big blob.

Oh, this is something I can speak on! Hi, I do content design stuff for the game.

So, while the Columbia District was properly part of the Hudson Bay Company by the start of the game period, it did enjoy a modest amount of autonomy, and also was subject to a condominium with the United States, and we didn't want to totally ignore the joint occupancy agreed to under the Treaty of 1818. With these considerations in mind, we felt it best to represent the region as its own tag rather than an integrated part of the Hudson Bay Company.

2021-08-13 15:40:45+02:00

Wizzington commented on Anyone else discouraged by the heavy economy focus?

The main pillars of the game are economy, politics and (to a slightly lesser degree) diplomacy. It may feel like economy is disproportionally important compared to the other two right now, but I think that's more down to the fact that we've just had more dev diaries about it than anything. There will be plenty of dev diaries coming on politics, diplomacy and even war in the future. With that said, Victoria 3 for sure is and should be a game with a heavy focus on economics, and that is not going to change.

2021-08-17 12:21:20+02:00

KaiserJohan commented on Would small, resource poor country be able to develop competitive industry and stable economy in 19th century?

You can either join another market to access its goods or maintain your own and import what you lack, assuming you can afford the infrastructure required to do so.

Equador in the game right now (subject to change ofc) has wood/iron/coal albeit not in great quantities plus a useful variety of agricultural options. I think the main challenge would be improving literacy to properly industrialize and reforming your laws and institutions.

I find Denmark an interesting challenge. You have a modern state with an educated populace but very few raw resources, more so than Sweden.

2021-05-21 22:18:33+02:00

Wizzington commented on Day and night cycles

The game is indeed divided into 4 ticks per day to give it a roughly equivalent campaign play time (depending on speed of course!) to a 400-year game, but we don't have anything like graphical day/night.

2021-05-22 01:17:40+02:00

Wizzington commented on Day and night cycles

Traum77 said:

Curious - is there a gameplay component to the different phases? I.e. do POPs produce during the day phases and consume during the night?

No, we don't simulate local time or anything like that and a global night of course makes no sense.

2021-05-22 01:33:12+02:00

KaiserJohan commented on Day and night cycles

Traum77 said:

Curious - is there a gameplay component to the different phases? I.e. do POPs produce during the day phases and consume during the night?

Not like that no but some game systems update on weekly tick, others on daily tick and a few on time-of-day ticks Smile :)

2021-08-16 08:48:20+02:00

hagerhink commented on Please stick to one timeframe (weekly/monthly/yearl) in tool-tips and infoboxes

You are correct that this is confusing. Most of the numbers in game, especially the ones related to the economy, are based on the weekly tick. Some of the places pointed out in this thread has now been clarified (like the Production Method tooltip). The annual numbers on the Building screen are in part a remnant from early development when the numbers were much smaller (most Pops generally made something like £0.001 weekly), so showing that annually was a necessity to be able to differentiate between the different Pop Types. It also ties in to some other screens, which means that removing/reworking that might be slightly bigger task, so fixing that will be a matter of priority.

Wizzington commented on Portugal: Here we go again

2021-08-04 16:52:17+02:00

Wizzington commented on Portugal: Here we go again

wilcoxchar said:

Already have, and yes I have low vision. There's no need to insult me or others who don't have perfect vision for a physical limitation we often can't control.

That should not be a reason to excuse bad design in any case. Paradox should be designing their games for accessibility be consider people with vision limitations when designing the game's interface, and that includes color schemes. Countries near or likely to be near each other need to having distinct enough colors to be able to tell apart immediately at a glance.

With the amount of countries we have compared to the colors actually available, this is much more of a tall order than you might think, especially for a country with a global presence like Portugal that is 'near' dozens of other countries. We also don't want to just completely ignore national colors associated with certain countries when assigning map colors.

Early arms production mostly uses iron, but steel starts being involved in tier 2 techs, so it's not much earlier than in history.

Wizzington commented on What is the difference between the Peasant and Farmer Pop type?

Karlburg said:

Peasants represent people in pre-modern economic arrangements- subsistence farmers. Farmers represent people in modern agricultural arrangements, paying significant rents, sharecropping, working plantations, etc. They definitely have different dynamics going on.

This is correct.

2021-07-03 22:48:01+02:00

hagerhink commented on The UI has a big issues, and in my humble opinion, I feel like it needs a rework.

Thanks for your feedback! When it comes to white-space, at this point of time in the development process I’d rather err on the side of having ”too much” rather than ”too little”. Especially given how much time the rest of the design team spends iterating on functionality and adding more complexity to the game. Making things tighter is always going to be much easier than cramming things in. All of the UIs are also very much WIP, and will be continuously polished as we get closer to release!

Wizzington commented on How will the german Confederation be represented in game?

At the moment we do not have any special mechanics for The German Confederation. I wouldn't say it's out of the question that we might have special content or some mechanics relating to it on release, but it is one of those areas where we have to make choices about what we do and do not have time for on release, and as much as the German Confederation (and the preceding HRE) are among my favorite historical entities (what can I say, I like silly German pseudo-state formations...) I don't think it would be justified to take too much time away from the core mechanics of the game for a niche system like this. It's for sure something I'd want to have in the game at some point, though.

2021-07-02 10:19:09+02:00

Wizzington commented on POPs and the Evolution of their "Interests"

One way that our system does support this is that it isn't like 100% of the aristocracy is in the Landowners group, and the logic for which pops tend to join what are fully scriptable so that specific circumstances in your country can increase or decrease the tendency for individuals within a Pop to join a specific IG. For example, the Trade Unions start out with very weak attraction across the board but grow stronger from the spread of ideas like Egalitarianism and Socialism.

2021-07-02 10:20:10+02:00

Wizzington commented on POPs and the Evolution of their "Interests"

Al-Khalidi said:

I would hope for more flexibility too, for example with clergy sometimes actually working in alliance with intelligentsia (increasing literacy, religious intellectualists or clergy thinkers were pretty common)

The Devout are actually in favor of religious schools that increase literacy, it's just that they want to control that education as much as possible, and the Intelligentsia do prefer religious schools to no schools at all, so it's possible for them to work together if they have a shared goal.

2021-05-21 22:13:57+02:00

Wizzington commented on Are there no political parties in Vic III?

There will be a dev diary about this coming in the not too distant future! What I can say for now is that we want the political simulation to work in all forms of societies, even ones where political parties wouldn't really be a thing due to for example being an autocracy without any form of formal political system. I can also say that political ideologies (liberalism, socialism etc) are for sure a huge thing in the game's political system.

2021-05-21 23:12:32+02:00

Wizzington commented on Are there no political parties in Vic III?

TheDungen said:

As long as a pop can belong to more than one group I like it, it reminds me of the democracy games.

Interest Groups are supported by individuals in Pops rather than whole Pops, so a Pop can lend support to multiple interest groups.

2021-05-22 15:21:26+02:00

Wizzington commented on Are there no political parties in Vic III?

Zhetone said:

the opposite seemed true to me, what it seemed he was saying that the catholic farmers in province A can have split loyalties, i.e. 25% support one ideology, 25% another, the remaining 50% yet another

A pop consists of X individuals, of those Y are politically enfranchised (how many depends on your laws) out of the politically enfranchised the different individuals can support any number of different interest groups and/or be non active (not lending their political strength to anyone). Made up on the spot example: if you have a pop of 40k, out of which 10k are enfranchised, you might have 3k supporting the Landowners, 2k supporting the Intelligentsia and 5k that are politically non-active.

2021-05-24 17:48:28+02:00

Wizzington commented on Are there no political parties in Vic III?

So now that PDXCON is over and we've had a chance to take in the reactions to the announcement, I just want to say that we've heard your concerns about political parties, we're actively discussing the role they should play in the politics system right now, and more details about this will be forthcoming in a dev diary at some point in the future Smile :)

2021-07-02 00:56:20+02:00

KaiserJohan commented on Infamy

Infamy/badboy as you know it is gone and replaced by new mechanics. Will be expained in a future dev diary Smile :)

2021-06-30 17:53:06+02:00

Wizzington commented on Wiz Twitter teaser 6

Lucododosor said:

The politically inactive group sounds interesting. What will make them increase/decrease over time? What are the consequences of a large politically inactive group in a said pop? Looking forward to the DD now.

Literacy, profession and social techs are the main determinants of political inactivity. Generally, poorer, less literate, and less class conscious pops will have a greater number of inactive individuals, which effectively means that those individuals' political strength is 'wasted'.

2021-06-30 17:55:43+02:00

Mr. Wiggles said:
