Yeah, the dependents shown here are basically the families of these engineers.

2021-06-30 18:50:23+02:00

Wizzington commented on Wiz Twitter teaser 6

PatriotCreeper said:

Sounds like if you wanted to do that you'd have to enact policy that makes it more likely for those pops to be illiterate and poor. Stuff like not having any education system, or trying to raise the price of goods they need.

Honestly, trying to put the genie back in the bottle like this isn't likely to really help you, at least in the short to medium term. If your population already is poor and illiterate you can try to keep them that way, but intentionally impoverishing your people to make them less politically active is going to create a lot of angry radicals.

2021-06-25 20:26:12+02:00

lachek commented on A Small Comment on Labour Elasticities and Income Shares of Different Factors in Victoria 3

First off, great post. Love the analysis of game mechanics implications in real-life terms. The analysis is correct in many ways, particularly in how every perturbation demand adjustments toward a stable equilibrium (between multiple agents, at that) - this needs to happen at a rate fast enough to make effective corrections without the economy crashing but not so fast as to cause ping-pong effects. This is something we're tweaking pretty frequently to make sure effects are tangible and understandable without being disastrous.

One piece of the puzzle you might be missing is that employers are also considered part of the building's workforce, and draw a wage from it in addition to collecting the dividends from its profits. Since each building is considered to be a whole industrial sector and not just a single business, in order for more workers to be hired the building also needs to "hire" the employer as well. For example, with a given Production Method configuration, a single factory might require 1 Capitalist for every 2 Engineers for every 4 Machinists for every 10 Laborers in order to increase operation by one "step." For the sake of argument let's say this is the workforce of 1 (very) small business.

Due to the rules of supply and demand, this actually means that the most profitable building from the employer's perspective is the one with minimal throughput, since this will keep input goods cost at minimum and output goods revenue at maximum. Being the only guy in town employing staff to produce these goods is obviously best. But from the perspective of the player, when they construct another "level" of Furniture Manufactories, they're developing the sector to a degree sufficient to employ maybe 5000 people, not 17. This means that in the game's fiction, there's actually several competing businesses opening operation, all clamoring for labor to realize their revenue. So even though it would be economically rational for the Furniture Manufactory "building" as a whole to cease hiring ASAP if they operated from the perspective of the best interest of the owner, that isn't going to happen. Instead the building operates from the perspective of what's rational for the player, who after all paid to lay the groundwork for all those new industries, and that is full employment. So as long as there's available jobs in the building, it will hire more and more people (including employers) even though this decreases the dividends for each individual employer. And if the building hits a point where it can no longer hire people at the current wage, it will increase the rate of wages it pays out if its profits permit, until it either runs out of profits to pay out or runs out of potential jobs to hire for.

Subsistence Farms act in a way as the "elasticity" in the system, since redundant or grossly underpaid employees will return to working as Peasants on Subsistence Farms if there's room for them to do so.

2021-06-13 16:46:09+02:00

Wizzington commented on Regarding the devs saying that we play as "soul of nation rather than leadership" to justify players building private industries

This was specifically in response to the argument that it's 'unrealistic' for the player to be able to do things that are outside the purview of the government, even though there's plenty of other things players can do that makes no sense if you're just playing the government (such as backing a revolution to overthrow yourself).

Ultimately what the player is and isn't allowed to do comes down to what the game loop is like, and which gameplay experiences we want to present. I recognize that there are people who would like the private economy sector part of the game to be a largely hands off experience (under certain economic systems), but we simply do not want one of the core features of the game to be locked off for the player. Building construction is so fundamental to how Victoria 3 plays that it would be akin to taking away the ability to declare war in EU4.

As I said in the dev diary, we are considering how exactly to handle investment, and I'm not ruling out capitalist-directed investment/construction instead of a more player-controlled investment pool (or some sort of hybrid) if we can get it work well, but we are not going to block the player from constructing private industries with state money if they want to do so. If you want to get into the realism arguments here, state grants to private industries is something that happens all the time in real life and I do not know of any examples of capitalist countries outlawing spending government money in such a way.

2021-06-13 17:07:41+02:00

Wizzington commented on Regarding the devs saying that we play as "soul of nation rather than leadership" to justify players building private industries

Shadowstrike said:

I'm not sure the argument is that "the state cannot build factories" or "the state cannot give subsidies to build factories", but rather about the relative distribution of who builds how many factories. Granted, I'm not sure how the gameplay loop would change if you went to a model where individual capitalists build more of the factories versus the player (or where it is more economic for the player to put down different amounts of subsidies to get factories built, with no guarantee that those will be taken up).

That said playing as "the spirit of the country" is kind of abstract, versus "playing as the government of the day". In the case of supporting a revolution, that might be thought of as changing who the player is (to the revolutionaries, rather than the government). It feels like an attempt to hybridize between HoI4, where you are clearly the government, and EU4 where you are a more abstract eminence grise.

I would challenge the idea that you're clearly playing the government in HOI4 given how many play-throughs depend on overthrowing the government to get a different ideology in power. Ultimately, who you play in our games is always going to be nebulous (even in Crusader Kings you can do things that are clearly against the interest of the character you're supposedly playing, like try to get killed in battle so your genius heir can take over) simply because of the scope of grand strategy. This is really only an issue if you overthink it, as most actions you take tend to fall within the scope of the government, or at least the ruling elite, but there's always exceptions simply because it's a game, not a perfect simulation of reality.

2021-06-13 17:18:28+02:00

Wizzington commented on Regarding the devs saying that we play as "soul of nation rather than leadership" to justify players building private industries

Pyoro said:

It's a tricky one; since the argument at face value makes sense and nobody's here actually played the game yet. Why take away a gameplay element from the player? Nobody likes being unable to DoW in EU either ... but, oh, here's the Regency Council, and suddenly you can't. Because that means events matter; there's actual weight to decisions and what's going on in the game even if it's inconvenient and annoying. It's not that anyone like being out of control, it's not that people expect an AI-controlled economy to be without it's annoyances, it's that it makes the decision on whether you want control or not an impactful and meaningful one.

If I recall correctly, Victoria III was compared to "country gardening", this sort of "grow your own nation" sort of feel. But that's only interesting if there's also a challenge to it; otherwise I might as well just go and write out some embarrassing alt.history fiction and draw some imaginary borders on a map. If I want to achieve something, I want to have hurdles to overcome, and giving up control in exchange for something else is an interesting one (as we know from Vicky II).

The other thing is that decision need to feel like they matter. Just having "+5% GDP" in a submenu, and, woo, now I got a different flag, that's a bit of flavor. And that's fine for a while, but surely we've moved beyond that? Mechanical differences are where the real meat is. This is a game after all.

Ultimately, as with gardening, I might be into growing a bonsai, where I control every single piece every single day. Or I may be more into growing an organic garden where I just keep some broad control but otherwise enjoy looking into what it's growing into without my constant interference. And obviously if I want to grow a tropical garden in Scandanvia I got a real challenge at my hands, it shouldn't just be possibly because, hey, I have decided so ...

Do not confuse the ability to make decisions with the automatic ability to make successful decisions. The fact that we want to give the player more control over growing and shaping their economy doesn't mean that their decisions can't end up really bad for their nation. If anything, the ability to make decisions and see the cause and effect of how they play out is pretty much what a strategy game is all about.

2021-06-13 17:37:35+02:00

Wizzington commented on Regarding the devs saying that we play as "soul of nation rather than leadership" to justify players building private industries

I do want to clarify that regardless what solution we end up with for investment funds, the player will always be limited in how they can use them to uses that directly benefit the investor class, and will never be able to, for example, use investment fund money to expand government services or pay the army.

2021-06-13 17:59:06+02:00

Wizzington commented on Regarding the devs saying that we play as "soul of nation rather than leadership" to justify players building private industries

Alfred Dreyfus said:

The fact you need to clarify the player can't magically use POPs non-taxed private money to pay the state army says a lot about the wrong direction you've taken.

Sorry for being so harsh about this decision, but I really think it makes Vic3 not a Vic2 sequel at all, it's just a different type of game now.

I fully understand and respect that this is the line in the sand that you have drawn for yourself, but that doesn't mean it's the universal line in the sand of what makes Victoria 3 a Victoria game (and by this logic, it also means that Victoria 2 was not a sequel to Victoria 1 since it radically changed how the economy worked from that game). Everyone will have a different idea of what is and is not necessary for a true Victoria game, and ultimately it's up to us as designers to try and deliver on our vision of what Victoria 3 should be while remaining open to feedback and course corrections.

I have already stated on numerous occasions that the way the investment pool works right now may change to a less player-controlled model (and this was a conversation that was ongoing even before the announcement), but we're going to make that decision after discussing, trying things out, prototyping, and seeing what we actually feel works when we try it in-game. This is how our design process works and repeating your argument in harsher tones isn't going to change anything.

2021-06-24 21:40:10+02:00

Wizzington commented on Government Administration buildings' local effect: the saga continues

MTGian said:

I know that assumptions can be dangerous things if they fail to become reality, but I continue to assume that government administration will obviously be needed locally. Not only that, but that the larger the population, the larger the local government needed. Why? Because I have faith in the development team.

Look at the amount of detail that is going into the economy. It would be wildly inconsistent for the developers that designed that system to model something where there is no local administration. That makes no sense. If the point of the game is economy/political gardening, then building a local bureaucracy is clearly part of that.

The only thing that is odd is that a developer hasn't just nipped this in the bud. Something like "We aren't idiots. Obviously, the government has some local presence and that will be modelled in game. The end." My assumption is they are busy or they are still working out the exact system or they aren't monitoring the forums that closely.

But I will be absolutely shocked if the final product has the player piling all government administration buildings in the capital and building nothing in the states.

Usually if we're not commenting on something like this, it's because we're not yet ready to talk about it, either because it's something we're actively iterating on or because it's a piece of information we want to reveal later in a different context.

For now, all I will say is that no, we don't want the optimal way to run your bureaucratic apparatus in a sprawling empire to just be a single giant Government Administration in your capital.

2021-06-01 18:54:55+02:00

Wizzington commented on Will we be able to stay an absolute monarchy on Victoria III ?

Yes, though you may find it challenging to do so if you also want to have full education, a liberalized economy and other such factors that will result in a strong base of IGs pushing for voting rights. Much easier to do if you remain agrarian and largely illiterate. Either way it should definitely be possible.

2021-06-01 22:09:32+02:00

lachek commented on Will we be able to stay an absolute monarchy on Victoria III ?

Prince Ire said:

How much flexibility is available in setting up ruling coalition from various IGs? For example, would it be possible to create something akin to the "conservative socialism" Metternich envisioned (though never implemented) late in his political career, a absolutist monarchical regime with strong social safety nets and government intervention in the economy; essentially, the aristocracy and the proletariat teaming up to screw over the bourgeoisie?

Yes, you will be able to do this. It will be a balancing act, because the aristocracy and the proletariat tend to have different ideas about how a country should be run. But with the right laws and political strength distribution in your population, it should be possible to keep such a coalition in power. And everything is of course easier to pull off if you can make people financially content.

2021-06-01 23:29:17+02:00

Wizzington commented on Will we be able to stay an absolute monarchy on Victoria III ?

Eh up me duck said:

Imperial Germany managed to build a pretty strong economy without too many concessions to liberals.

As Mikael said, one way to keep people in line is to make sure they're economically prosperous, so you can definitely go down the route of trying to increase the wealth of your pops without giving them rights, but this may come very well back and bite you if the good times stop rolling.

2021-06-02 00:58:33+02:00

Wizzington commented on Will we be able to stay an absolute monarchy on Victoria III ?

cristofolmc said:

I guess all remains to ask is: will it be possible to remain a competitive country with a competitive economy with a strong agrarian economy? ie the confederate states? Because in vicky2 the game forced you as the confederate states to abandon such economic model and go full industrial, which is quite absurd.

It is supposed to be a viable strategy to focus primarily on agriculture and/or resource extraction yes, at least if you have the arable land and resource base to support it. This pairs very well with a more conservative political playstyle.

2021-06-21 15:07:16+02:00

hagerhink commented on Heat maps, states and general country structure

Note: There is a big difference between visualizing the in-game data using a heat map and having the underlying data saved as something resembling a heat map.

2021-06-17 09:49:27+02:00

KaiserJohan commented on New Wiz teaser from Twitter

Arbus said:

I believe the green numbers represent the number of factories/farms/mines you can build.

That's why you have room for 30 factories, of any type, but a limited number of farms and mines depending on the fertility, arable land and natural resources available.

Urban centers are "zero" because you can't build them, they appear automatically as a result of urbanization.

It shows "number of states where you can build this building". The factories can be built in any state (except Shipyards require Coastal state) but the resource buildings require that resource to be present Smile :)

2021-06-10 23:20:04+02:00

It's the Miskito Kingdom, yep.

2021-06-10 10:07:29+02:00

Wizzington commented on Canals

Building smaller canals as a game mechanic would make more sense with an earlier start date, as it is they would compete too quickly with railroads in 1836 start.

Representing important canals with state traits is an interesting idea though.

2021-06-10 16:00:27+02:00

Wizzington commented on Canals

Avernite said:

That's exactly what they did though; the Netherlands were sluggish at building railroads because canals (including new ones) were almost as good for a long time. And when railway got certainly better (rather than about equal as early on), the Netherlands lagged behind as a result.

I'm not disagreeing on a historical basis, but when it comes to actually creating mechanics, implementing canals in such a way means we'd basically be adding something that's directly competing with an early tech that the player would know is better in the long run. In terms of gameplay it would be a bit of a pointless addition unless we could actually find a distinct niche for them.

2021-06-07 08:22:10+02:00

lachek commented on Slave Interest Groups

There are Interest Groups in favor of abolition, but the slaves themselves do not have any political strength with which to support these groups. Their way of getting their voices heard is more direct, by necessity.

2021-06-07 17:20:49+02:00

lachek commented on Slave Interest Groups

Grave461 said:

How well will Vic3 handle situations like what happened in the USA leading up to the Civil War? For example, the US was hesitant to ratify certain territories into statehood, in fear that they would take a pro-slavery stance.

If we were in a similar situation in Vic3, would the game "know" which IG to support in regards to slavery/abolition (based perhaps on geographic regions, ie; north/south), or will we more likely see arbitrary blobs where a state or two in the north may be pro-slavery, one or two in the south favor abolitionists? In the US at least, it was very geographically based (hence the reluctancy to ratify statehood for southern territories at the time).

Would love to try and navigate through my own A House Divided scenario.

This is entirely emergent from the simulation, which at the moment runs a little something like this:

  1. Wealthy Aristocrats are more likely to support the Landowner Interest Group, which in the USA's case is called the Southern Planters and have a pro-Slavery stance

  2. The American south has a lucrative Plantation industry at game start, with potential to expand that doesn't exist in the north

  3. Pops in incorporated states gain more Political Strength than Pops in unincorporated states

  4. Wealthier Pops gain more Political Strength on account of their wealth

  5. More Political Strength means more power over the country's Laws, and a stronger reaction if the player tries to move away from favored Laws

Which means that it's the relative profitability of the American south's slave plantations that cause the Southern Planters to have the political support they do. If the player nurtures this type of plantation economy the institution of slavery will become an even more dominant and important fixture of US politics, whereas if they shift their economy towards manufacturing industries (perhaps in part fueled by resources from plantations in UNincorporated states, where the Aristocrats may be wealthy but not as politically empowered) or service/government workers, they may be able to effect a political shift away from slavery without a civil war.

2021-06-02 23:04:19+02:00

lachek commented on Pop types and interest groups, Engineers no clear group

Meanmanturbo said:

Maybe they will be a pop type very sensitive to its economic standing more then natural ideaology.

Yeah, Professions never map 1:1 to Interest Groups, secondary attributes like Wealth and Literacy can matter a lot to its political support distribution. Engineers, as you guessed, can swing in a number of different directions.

2021-06-03 20:33:33+02:00

Wizzington commented on Capacities -- what do you think?

Cymsdale said:

The developers should have never fallen into the trap by saying they "don't have mana". They gave credibility to a meaningless complaint based on a snarl world whose definition changes arbitrarily.

Paradox makes grand strategy games and grand strategy games are going to have abstractions in them. How good those abstractions are should individually be judged on their own merits and not based on if someone calls it mana or not.

I can see your point, but at the same time we didn't want the first couple of weeks of discussion about Victoria 3 to just be an endless debate on whether or not there would be mana in the game, which is likely what would have happened if we'd said nothing on the subject. Ultimately though, everyone has their own definition of the word and I think the more relevant point is what degree of abstraction is suitable for each particular game: in Victoria 3 we're striving for more grounded mechanics in general.

2021-06-02 18:56:09+02:00

Wizzington commented on Unpopular opinion but I think Victoria will be better off without achievements

There will be achievements in Victoria 3.

2021-06-02 19:03:57+02:00

Wizzington commented on What about the smaller German states like Hesse, Nassou, and Bavaria?

It should certainly be possible (with varying degrees of challenge, Anhalt is certainly ultra-hard-mode) to stay independent as one of the German minors. The challenge to do so should come in averting the ambitions of Prussia and Austria though, not a 'and now you die' event.

2021-05-25 16:12:27+02:00

Wizzington commented on Did somebody say Victoria III

Nice to see you again, I played a whole lot of VIP way back in the days of Vicky 1 Smile :)

2021-06-02 12:35:42+02:00

Wizzington commented on Victoria 3 Game Vision Video

Alfred Dreyfus said:

I don't like that much the idea of "British POPs will consume a lot of tea".

I mean, I hope is a small modifier, not a huge one. Something like "+10%" would be kind of cool, but I hope is not something unrealistic like "+50%".

It should be a small detail, not something that influences the game that much.

Have a look at differences in modern tea consumption to get an idea of how just how much cultural/regional preferences can matter: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_tea_consumption_per_capita

If anything, having something like this be a 10% bonus would be what would be unrealistic/ahistorical. The british tea craze indirectly led to the opium wars, it was a huge deal.

2021-05-25 15:20:18+02:00

KaiserJohan commented on What other Paradox game mechanics or things do you want or not want in Vic 3?

Just curious (and completely unrelated to Victoria 3) what is it about EU4 Age mechanics you don't like? Personally I found it neat by giving you new goals, a central "theme" and locking/unlocking game mechanics. Kinda shaking up the game a little abit every century Smile :)

2021-05-22 21:30:18+02:00

Wizzington commented on Will the Empire of Brazil receive some sweet flavor?

I don't want to go into too much detail on what content we have at this stage but I can say we do have the Ragamuffin War as that was going on at the start of the game.

2021-05-24 00:44:25+02:00

Wizzington commented on Will the Empire of Brazil receive some sweet flavor?

MinhowMinhow said:

But Ragamuffin war already at full war in early 1836 is a mistake.

Regency era was very unstable in Brazil. There were two main groups in 1836 Moderados (Moderated) and Exaltados (Exalteds), that were struggling for power. The Moderados, that in 1840 would become the Conservatives, were for centralized power and were supported by upper classes. The Exaltados, the Liberals were for federal power and had more support of lower classes.

The Ragamuffin war started because they wanted more autonomy, with a federal system. Another issue was economical, they wanted more tariffs, because they were the biggest producer of meat, but foreign meat was much more cheaper to import and buy in brazilian market.

The Ragamuffin rebelled in september 1835, expelled the governor, sent a letter to regent explaing the situation and appointed a new governor, they considered that the rebellion ended at that point, because at start separatism wasn't an issue, they were more of a particularist revolt. But the regent appointed a new governor in late 1835, to have full control of state, but only arrived in january 1836, sent an army and then deposed the ragamuffin governor, but the war fully started in september 1836.

So at that point the player can decide if support the ragamufin governor and the liberal faction or expel the governor and support the conservative. There should be an option to rebel too and form another nation.

Doesn't make sense for a liberal player, to start the game killing a liberal revolt, that is considered in game as nationalist, but actually didn't even fully started. Tariffs were an issue too, so for a high tariff Brazil, this wouldn't had happened too.

It's a diplo play that hasn't become a war yet at game start.

2021-05-27 14:14:50+02:00

Wizzington commented on Is 1836 Start Date Really the Best Choice?

Not to try and shut down discussion or anything, as anyone is of course welcome to disagree with our decision here and discuss why they would do it differently, I just want to make clear that the start date is not going to change. 1836-1936 is what we set down years ago and what we will have for release, 100% certain.

2021-05-27 17:46:14+02:00

Wizzington commented on Those pesky rebels. How will/should be represented?

Without going too much into detail I can say that the aim is have fewer but more dangerous rebellions, and more forms of 'limited' civil unrest so the constant first resort of angry pops isn't rising up and marching on the capital. We also want all rebellions to have the potential for foreign involvement.

2021-05-27 13:49:23+02:00

hagerhink commented on I am tired, specifically of people bashing/crapping on the UI and map so hard.

Personally: As long as the feedback is constructive, I appreciate it and will try to take as much of it into consideration when working on the game.

2021-05-27 13:14:24+02:00

Wizzington commented on Is it possible to confirm the relationship status between Qing and Joseon at the start of the game?

Korea is currently a Tributary (highly autonomous subject) of Qing at game start

2021-05-27 13:20:14+02:00

Wizzington commented on Is it possible to confirm the relationship status between Qing and Joseon at the start of the game?

RhoxOS said:

Hi, thanks for the reply. If that's the case could we also get why Vietnam has a separate border and Korea has not?

Generally we're not representing every tributary of Qing as a subject, it depends on how much the Qing government tended to meddle in their domestic affairs in the mid-19th century.

There might well be an argument that Korea should be treated as fully independent (same as say, Dai Nam or Nepal), to my knowledge the Qing were generally more directly involved in Korea in the mid-19th century than in many of the other tributaries but I'm hardly an expert on the subject.

2021-05-27 14:07:44+02:00

Wizzington commented on Is it possible to confirm the relationship status between Qing and Joseon at the start of the game?

RhoxOS said:

Thanks. I think that gave us some idea on the classification of subjects. Have a good day.

What countries to represent and not represent as subjects and which types can be a super tricky subject to research and make a decision and I'm certainly not confident we will get everything right, so I do think conversations on topics like this are important. Ultimately the goal is to get as close to history as we can in the game mechanics we have.

2021-05-27 13:24:06+02:00

hagerhink commented on UI: Significant digits in the interface

This is very reasonable feedback, and something that we try to improve constantly. Most of the time it is defined on case-by-case basis, so it is the type of fix that is very simple and fast to fix for a single occurrence, but near impossible to "get right" everywhere. That being said, 1) is now fixed and we'll continue to fix those as we find them.

2021-05-22 01:06:04+02:00

Wizzington commented on The Grand Duchy of Finland needs to be in Victoria III's starting scenario(s)

Finland is a a subject nation of Russia in 1836 in Victoria 3.

2021-05-22 01:09:52+02:00

Wizzington commented on The Grand Duchy of Finland needs to be in Victoria III's starting scenario(s)

Vernichtere said:

According to logic, other parts of the tsarist empire should also have some kind of status. If you do something like that, it should be a general game mechanic. You either don't have enough control over a province or you have certain rights to keep the people quiet. For example, I can exempt Poland from compulsory military service, but still collect taxes. Or they can determine their own market. Or I allow the state to have its own army.

The problem with an independent Finland is simple. I have to annex the land directly, probably by conquest, if I want direct control. But that's not how it happened historically. At the turn of the century, the tsarist empire tried to gradually curtail rights. It was a process and not a relationship between two subjects.

We try to make a historical judgment on how much autonomy different parts of empires had when deciding whether they should be an annexed incorporated, annexed unincorporated, or subject (of varying degrees of autonomy). For example we considered whether Poland should be a puppet instead of annexed territory, but their autonomy was basically entirely gone by 1836 so it didn't really make sense to us.

2021-05-22 01:13:53+02:00

Wizzington commented on The Grand Duchy of Finland needs to be in Victoria III's starting scenario(s)

Kyoumen said:

I would think, given other things revealed, that trying to better integrate a subject nation would be something you could do in the game without having to declare war, but at the risk of radicalising the population and having other countries support the subject nation's attempts to get further autonomy or freedom. Several examples of this from the era.

It is possible to annex and curtail subject autonomy without going to war, but there's a risk of other countries getting involved and turning it into a proper conflict.

2021-05-22 15:07:24+02:00

Wizzington commented on The Grand Duchy of Finland needs to be in Victoria III's starting scenario(s)

Tehrozer said:

Thats sadly the issue of starting in 1836 Polish autonomy got revoked after the 1830-31 Uprising so there is no way of going around that. I guess there could be a decision to restore Kingdom of Poland should Russia decide to liberalise/reform its political structure and could be a interesting thing to represent.

And on a other note are there any chances to learn what other subject nations will Russia have at start?

That's a cool idea, I'll note that down for the content team (obligatory disclaimer that me saying something is a cool idea doesn't mean it's going to make it into release!)

2021-05-27 19:17:11+02:00

Wizzington commented on Women.

Dependents earn an income, this income is less than the workforce earns but still incredibly important to poor pops if there isn't minimum wages/social programs. Also, more liberal countries start with at least some women in the workforce to represent female factory workers, etc. So we are definitely not aiming to simulate all women as housewives.

2021-05-27 13:37:21+02:00

hagerhink commented on Will the UI be improved???

So, just to answer OP's original question (and a lot of the discussions related to it):

Yes, both the look and the functionality of the UI is a constant work in progress and it will be be worked on every day until release.

Also, yes, both the Victoria 3 team and the CK3 team has seen the CountCristo video.

KaiserJohan commented on Trade in Victoria 3?

RustyKraken said:

One of the most frustrating Victoria 2 experiences in my opinion is when the economy crashes a decade in for some obscure reason and it being no fault of your own.

2021-05-22 12:23:03+02:00

2021-05-25 23:17:12+02:00

Wizzington commented on Are pops individual or group based?

We track the number of literate individuals to get the %.

2021-05-25 23:32:19+02:00

Wizzington commented on Are pops individual or group based?

A billion individuals but not a billion pops since pops are a demographic slice of (often thousands of) individuals. We track things like literacy, radicalism, ig membership etc on an individual basis tho.

2021-05-25 23:33:35+02:00

Wizzington commented on El Dorado style country creation

It's a neat idea but out of scope for release.

2021-05-25 16:49:11+02:00

Wizzington commented on Does Infrastructure provide jobs?

There are indeed pops working in railroads, ports, etc and they do not function without them

2021-05-25 17:08:15+02:00

Wizzington commented on Does Infrastructure provide jobs?

OHgamer said:

This brings up a related issue in my mind. One area of the economy that V1 and V2 did not really model was the rise of the service economy in the late 19th century - everything from retail workers to office staff composed a large part of the new industrial economy yet their socioeconomic interests were often very different from factory workers (and this played out in elections as political systems democratized, much of the political support for the center right and later far right comes from these groups in the early 20th century) .

The service economy is modelled in the form of urbanization and urban centers growing as a result of industralization, etc. These produce services (more on how services work in the future).

2021-05-21 22:23:45+02:00

Wizzington commented on Start date: 1836

We actually did debate the start date internally but chose 1836 because there is a lot of things important to the era (South America, Belgium, etc) that just aren't in place in 1821.

2021-05-21 23:32:14+02:00

Wizzington commented on Start date: 1836

I will say this: If we were to ever add any more start dates to the game at some point, I think 1821 would be the strongest candidate - but for release at least we want to focus on the 'core century' 1836-1936.

2021-05-22 00:04:00+02:00

Centuria said:

Wizzington commented on Please let us have 1 tick / day as an option

This is fundamental to the architecture of the game and not something we can offer as an option.

There are nation forming mechanics, details will come at a later point!

KaiserJohan commented on Are Heads of State set in stone or randomized?

Like most of our games the historical rulers & heirs can be scripted in history setup but beyond that randomized. Of course you can have events replace them too. Smile :)

2021-05-22 15:04:32+02:00

Wizzington commented on No Mission (or Focus) Trees please

There are no current plans for mission or focus trees, as we feel setting down one (or a few) 'correct' paths would detract from the core society builder aspect of the game.

2021-05-23 01:39:00+02:00

Wizzington commented on No Mission (or Focus) Trees please

thedarkendstar said:

There will be other mechanics to encourage historical nation formations to happen.

2021-05-21 23:14:47+02:00

Wizzington commented on Flag Changes

Of course! We'll go into details about this at a later point but I suspect you will like what we have to show when it comes to flags.

2021-05-23 13:39:43+02:00

KaiserJohan commented on On managing expectations

Of course I'm biased so take it with a grain of salt but I would argue it's deeper and more comprehensively explained. When playing I can drill down into the numbers and (while it takes some time) stuff checks out. IMO some of Victoria 2's perceived complexity/mystique is it just not being transparent or explained enough.

<< Ducks into cover >> Big Grin :D

2021-05-22 21:20:37+02:00

Wizzington commented on How should Austria-Hungary be represented?

To my best understanding of history, Hungary did not have enough autonomy in 1836 to be accurately represented as a subject state at that time. You could make an argument for it after Austria became A-H but a very crucial part of A-H was Hungarian privileges and ambitions in regards to shared domination over other parts of the empire, so I'm not sure about that either. I'm of course open to changing my mind if there are compelling enough sources on the subject to indicate they should start as a subject.

2021-05-22 21:28:02+02:00

Wizzington commented on How should Austria-Hungary be represented?

Jia Xu said:

What would be the consequences of removing all of those provinces, though? If Hungary is a separate country, even as a subject, what happens to Austria's industrial and military scores? Is prestige enough to keep a rump Austria as a great power? Also what about the rest of the realm? Would Lombardy-Venetia and Bohemia also be subjects?

I have to ask you because I can only go on the rules of how Vicky2 worked to kind of pictures how any of this would work out. Obviously Vicky3 is going to be using different fundamentals but it seems like a dubious prospect so far.

Subjects' GDP and military power gives prestige to overlords in V3, so it shouldn't be a huge issue in terms of keeping Austria a GP (and shared market means they can still access Hungarian goods). I'm skeptical that it makes sense historically, though.

2021-05-21 23:27:54+02:00

Wizzington commented on Not all countries will be playable at launch (Potential first DLC?)

Kyoumen said:

While I am also fine with this, I can and would play an African nation (and there absolutely should be several of those in 1836), and getting away from the "this is not what this era was about" mindset is part of why this decision is exciting to me.

There will for sure be a number of playable African nations on release such as Sokoto, the Ethiopian and Somalian states, etc. We haven't finalized which will and will not be playable at this stage, but we're trying to root it as much in historical research around the level of centralization in those states as we can.

2021-05-22 00:36:04+02:00

Wizzington commented on Not all countries will be playable at launch (Potential first DLC?)

toegut said:

as I understand it, "decentralized" are not uncivs, they are literally blank map spaces in vicky 2, which can be colonized. What I'm missing is does the game have uncivs? @Wizzington ? you confirmed that sokoto will be playable from the start, will the gameplay as sokoto be the same as a european country or different?

Any country that was an 'unciv' in V2 is likely what we call an 'unrecognized nation' in V3 (basically a state of not being recognized as a potential equal by the European Great Powers which is penalizing mainly in terms of diplomacy and being seen as a legitimate target of conquest by recognized countries).

Those countries generally start with a lower level of technology (the degree to which will vary based on historical research - there are of course differences in the starting technology level of recognized powers too) and might have laws that make it difficult to industrialize but they don't have anything like '-25% to GDP due to being unrecognized'.

2021-05-22 14:57:26+02:00

Wizzington commented on Status of Norway

Norway starts as a subject (in a Personal Union under Sweden).

Wizzington is my alternative nickname that I use interchangably with Wiz, at some point it got changed here due to account unification or forums migration or somesuch.

2021-05-21 23:28:44+02:00

KaiserJohan commented on How hard was it to keep it a secret?

I think the community did a good job at figuring it out beforehand and yes it's been hard not being able to tell anyone what you've worked on for so long Big Grin :D

2021-05-21 23:55:23+02:00

Wizzington commented on The Key Question: Is Prussia Yellow?

Yellow Prussia was just too beautiful for this world, I'm afraid.

I'm sure it'll be a day 1 mod at any rate.

2021-05-22 12:16:32+02:00

KaiserJohan commented on Eternal cores

Cores/Claims works abit differently from before but that will be expanded on in a future dev diary Smile :)

2021-05-21 23:16:44+02:00

Wizzington commented on Capitalists cant build things?

One of our goals with this game is to put a lot more agency in the hands of the player when it comes to shaping the economic development of their nation. That doesn't mean we want it to devolve into a micromanagement fest of course, but more on that later on (I know I keep saying that but we have so many dev diaries to come and I don't want to get too ahead of them!)

2021-05-22 00:00:17+02:00

Wizzington commented on Capitalists cant build things?

toegut said:

"More player agency"? Isn't this in contradiction to the goal of simulation stated in the dev diary? I know it's the eternal debate, "oh, you want a simulation but that's boring because the game will play itself" but still I hope you guys sorted out how to strike this balance before starting development since it's the fundamental design concept of the game.

What we're aiming for is to give the player the agency to try and direct their country the way they please - but not with any guaranteed success. You make the choices, but that also means you have to deal with the consequences and reactions from the people in your nation who disagree with those choices and who might seek to overturn them.

I will say that I am not stating unequivocally that there will not be any autonomous construction of buildings though - just that the player will never be completely unable to interact with the building system, as it's such an integral part of the game's core loop.

2021-05-21 23:10:46+02:00

KaiserJohan commented on The screenshots show GBR as only the second most powerful GP in 1836. Which could be #1?

Darrenb209 said:

I'm going to be honest, if any European power is ahead of Great Britain in 1836 and it isn't caused by player interaction, something has gone wrong.

In 1836, the major powers of the world were all in Europe. China was in decline and the USA hadn't begun it's rise yet. France was in it's unstable "July Monarchy" even if it was the time period they went after Algeria and Russia only really began it's true ascent following the 1848 revolutions harming all the other powers in Europe. Austria, for all that it was just ending a period of being the dominant power in Europe, was only the dominant power in Europe.

Britain was the only power to have anything like a global reach during the time period and oddly one of the only major powers of the time to properly industrialise. Russia and Austria-Hungary can be counted alongside Spain for countries that performed a rapid industrialisation in the 20th century. Although at least with Spain they had the sense to industrialise a decent part of their country in the 1800s.

France and Germany, while they did Industrrialise properly. were not really major powers in 1836 when compared to Austria, Britain, Russia or even the Ottomans. The French were unstable and untrusted due to Napoleon and had very little reach and Germany had a good few years to go before becoming Germany rather than Prussia.

GBR starts as #1. Either something off in that build or they fiddled around before screenshotting Smile :)

2021-05-22 00:05:12+02:00

Wizzington commented on The screenshots show GBR as only the second most powerful GP in 1836. Which could be #1?

This is just down to non final balancing Smile :) the UK should for sure be the #1 great power in 1836.

So you've decided to abandon all history. You've decided to ignore the great empire of Lippe-Detmold. We shall not forget this slight.

Are you really implying that the glory of Lippe-Detmold can be judged on a mere earth-scale of power? I'm disgusted.

Of course there's lots of factories in Victoria 3, silly. There will be a dev diary on buildings coming in the not distant future.

2021-05-21 22:15:13+02:00

Wizzington commented on Graphs, Pie Charts and Information UI

If graphs and charts is your thing, I think you will be very happy with Vicky 3.

None

AAR : V3 OFFICIAL AAR #1 by Martin "Wiz" Anward

I will start the AAR here in little more than 30 minutes. As I play, I'll be taking screenshots quite a bit and trying to answer some questions from the AAR chat channel (the answers will be written here). Since this is the first 'official' AAR, I'd just like to remind people that I will be playing on hot code, so while the aim is to play for about 8 hours (with a break or two), there's a chance my game might become unstable or otherwise break. If this happens, I'll try to pick it up or restart it at a later time.

I will be playing as the Ottomans, with the goal of building up a rural-based economy, maintaining conservative values and a traditional power structure while also trying to reform and strengthen the empire and retake lost lands.

It's OK to ping me in v3-aar-general-chat to ask questions, just be aware that I will not answer every question. How many I answer will depend on how many there are and how much time it takes away from playing - it might be just a few, it might be a lot. With that in mind, please don't spam the same question.

Alright, it's time to start!

This is me, the Ottoman Empire of 1836, also known as the Sick Man of Europe. Now, you might be wondering how I got into this situation.

OCR: +77.6 +435 +1.02K € +1Z.8K January 7, 1836 Tuesday Morning 17.7M 18.900 9.0 19.SM 4.39K 575 (Paused) 0/20 Nothing Under Construction 'fanore Active Journal Entries The Sick Man of Europe The Sick Man of Europe 84 days Markets Austria Turkish Market Wallachia Serbia Sea Konya Ottoman Empire) Turkish Market (100% Market Access; +12 Infrastructure) Strategic Region: Anatolia Right-click to open Context Menu 7 { 62FPS Prus sia Annen Prussiz Goxum} Eelgim Bavaria 0 Cizerimd ~Ra Caspian Black 8ea Laruantic K h i v a Seu 6 Ottoman Bukhara 0 mpire Medlite Tanean Persia Afgh Seh Persian Tripolitania

OCR: The Sick Man of Europe Event in Thrace The Ottoman Empire is in a period of steady decline: If we do not reassert Ottoman sovereignty and reclaim our place among the Powers of the world, we risk catastrophe: We have fallen, but we can rise again. In an Auspicious Incident we deposed the Janissaries who had maintained their miserly grip on power for centuries, finally allowing reform to possible. is much more to do. First, of course, we need to replace the Janissaries with truly modern military force. But in addition; we must restore the place of the Sublime Porte as the very height of civilization. Education, urbanization, and sovereignty shall be the top items of the Ottoman agenda. Great reform is needed. There

There are those who would say that the Empire is outdated, outmoded, left behind by the European Great Powers due to archaic laws and customs such as the Jizya taxes or the largely agrarian economy. They would insist that the Empire needs to modernize, liberalize and industrialize, reform itself along Western lines by limiting the power of the monarch and giving that power to his subjects. To those people I say only one thing: pfah

OCR: +77.6 +435 1.02K { +17.8K January 7,1836 Tuesday Morning 17.7M 18.900 9.0 19.SM 439K 575 (Paused) POLITICS Active Jou The Overview Government Laws Institutions Power Structure Economy Human Rights Market Turkis Governance Principles Economic System Free Speech Monarchy Traditionalism 1 Censorship A Distribution of Power Trade Policy Labor Rights Autocracy 0 Mercantilism 0 Serfdom Abolished 2 Citizenship Taxation Children' s Rights Cultural Exclusion 0 Land-Based Taxation Child Labor Allowed A A Church and State Colonization Rights of Women State Religion 0 No Colonial Affairs 0 Legal Guardianship 4 Bureaucracy Welfare Hereditary Bureaucrats 0 No Police No Social 0 7 Army Model Education System Migration Peasant Levies 0 No Schools 02 No Migration Controls Nev Internal Security Health System Slavery No Home Affairs No Health System Slave Trade Nev Ac New New New Nev 163 FPS Policing Security

OCR: 'UTTOMAN -MPIRE Country Information Modifiers Diplomacy 145 p RTH 25 Timed Modifiers @€EAN Sick Man of Europe Remaining Time: Never E17,.7 25.0% Prestige Population 19.5M Literacy 18.9% Standard of Living Struggling 9.00) State Religion Sunni Government: Sultanate Primary Cultures Turkish Arable Land 30.5% 678 Infamy Reputable

OCR: cTTOMAN -MPIRE Country -KIL-AN Information Modifiers Diplomacy 145 25 Timed Modifiers Cizye Tax GDP Remaining Time: Never 17.7M +0.50 € Land Tax 40% Conscription rate Population 19.5M Literacy 18.9% Standard of Living Struggling 9.00) State Religion Sunni Government: Sultanate Primary Cultures Turkish Arable Land 30.5%6 678 Infamy Reputable Xiiant

OCR: ~OTTOMAN -MPIRE Country -ALILANTIL Information Modifiers Diplomacy 145 25 Timed Modifiers Outmoded Bureaucracy GDP Remaining Time: Never {17.7M ~25% Bureaucracy Population 19.SM Literacy 18.906 Standard of Struggling 9.00) State Religion Sunni Government: Sultanate Cultures Turkish Arable Land 30.5%6 Infamy Reputable AAN " Living Prinary

It is true that the Empire is weak, and in need of some reform. But the reason for that has nothing to do with our traditional ways of ruling, and everything to do with weak rulers who have allowed Western influences to creep into and weaken our realm. We will reform, and cast off the title of Sick Man, but we will do so in our own way, without losing who we are. We will crush the separatist movements, strengthen the army and retake Syria from the rebellious Governor of Egypt.

OCR: Journal Decisions Active Journal Entries The Sick Man of Europe The Sick Man of Europe Will complete if: X Complete 4 'Tanzimat' Journal Entries Tanzimat: Reclaim Syria Starting a diplomatic play against Egypt will give European Will time out in 19 years Great Powers an Active Interest in the region: If completed: Ottoman Empire oses Sick Man of Europe Tanzimat: Urbanization -25.0% Prestige Triggers the Event Tanzimat: The Reorganization Tanzimat: Education Reform If time runs out: Ottoman Empire loses Sick Man of Europe Tanzimat: Suppress Separatism -25.0% Prestige Triggers the Event The Dead Man of Europe Tanzimat: Modernization Tanzimat: Bureaucratic Reform Potential Journal Entries Religion, Autocracy, Nationality Kiie Cer Lnc Army

(Note: Jizya tax says Land Tax but it's actually a tax on Heathen pops)

Meet our primary antagonist, at least in the short term. Even though Egypt is rightfully an Ottoman province, and Muhammed Ali nominally recognizes our overlordship, in practice he rules an independent state that has conquered Syria and made the Hedjaz into a protectorate.

OCR: cGYPT Country Information Modifiers Diplomacy 129 39 Wallachia Timed Modifiers GDP {7.84M Population 9.33M Literacy 20.7% Standard of Impoverished (10.26) State Religion Sunni Government: Khedivate Cultures Misri Arable Land 46.8%6 360 Attitude Relations Infamy 7 f Belligerent Cold Reputable 9 Strategies Agricultural Conservative Defend the Investmnents Agenda Borders Black 8Bea mpire (ean Living Sel Prinary 2 2

Egypt was able to defeat us largely due to the poor state of the Ottoman army. Instead of maintaining a professional and well-equipped force, we rely heavily on a semi-feudal system of irregulars, which means that while on paper our army is quite large (and relatively cheap to maintain) it hasn't stood up well to Egypt's western-style forces. Our artillery is also outdated, and we depend on foreign imports to supply it.

OCR: GARRACKS in Thrace Information Workforce Modifiers Status: Active Employment: 25.0K Government Expenses: 7.28K Mobilized Battalions: 0 / 25 (0.00%) fia 25 bia Battalions Production Methods Greecc Murat Karaosmanoglu Garrisoned Process Weekly Balance: 0.7.28K Building` ptton ra

OCR: cARRACKS Ruildina i Thrace Organization Production Method Current: Irregular Infantry odifiers Unscaled Modifiers: 5 +15 Offense +10 Defense Total Modifiers: +500.0 Training Rate 14+50 Power Projection 0 -7.28K 25 (0.00%) Increased Employment: Servicemen: +24.2K Total Officers: +750 Total Show per Level values 3at | Applies to Barracks (Organization Production Method) Left-click to see available options" Murat Karaosmanoglu Spair Garrisoned 'rocess Weekly Balance: 0-7.28K Provides 25

OCR: Artillery Support Production Method Current: Cannon Unscaled Modifiers: +10 +10 Defense Defense H Inford +10.0% Morale Damage +10.0% Kill Rate Total Modifiers: 1+25 Power Projection Goods Consumption: Artillery: +25.0 Total 105.0 Show per Level values Requires one of the following: Artillery talions Applies to Barracks (Artillery Support Production Method) Left-click to see available options" Murat Karaosmanoglu Garrisoned cess Weekly Balance: €-7.28K Provides 25 Artillery

We have claims on them, and this will tie into events that might come later.

OCR: Raikin Idag 16.15 @Martin Wiz" Anward Are there any play mechanics that show the nominal overlordship over egypt? game

Struggling is worse than impoverished

OCR: nudu 16.15 Ottomans have 9.0 standart of living and it says struggling, Egypt has 10.26 and it's impoverished Is less better? @Martin` Wiz" Anward Idaz

Our finances are okay-ish at the moment. Our main sources of income are land/jizya and consumption taxes.

OCR: Money Balance: € +17.8K 4 Gold Reserves 2.35M Investment Pool: 0.00 (Change: € 0.00} National Revenue: +113K [+27.6K Income Taxes [+54.0K Poll Taxes [+18.0K Consumption Taxes [+3.92K Tariffs {+9.1OK Minting {+762 Diplomatic Pacts National Expenses: $.95.6K f-1L1K Goods for Government Buildings 5.30.5K Government [.20.6K Goods for Buildings {.31.9K Wages [-127K Construction Wages {-58.0 Subsidies Balance +18.7K OOK 1 Jan, 1836 7 Jan, 1836 Gold Reserves 2.37M 5,09M Jan; 836 7 Jan, 1836 Wages Military Military

We are a Major Power, with some potential to become a Great Power if we can get rid of the hefty prestige penalty from Sick Man of Europe. We have an old rivalry with Russia, and we maintain loose overlordship of Wallachia, Moldavia, Serbia and Tunis, as well as firmer control of Tripoli

OCR: cIPLOMACY ustria Major Power Wallachia Serhia Overview Release Subject Interest in Danubia Balkans Arabia Anatolia [ Se Caucasus North Africa Diplomatic Status Rivalty Protectorate Puppet Truces Bmaria Ottoman Madlita ranean Tripolitania Tibesti, A i r

Our first reform goal will be to Modernize the Army. There's a lot of areas we don't want to emulate the West in, but the army is one of them, as it's clear that we have no chance of reclaiming Syria, Egypt and our other lost territories otherwise. To do this, there's a few things we're going to need to do: - Switch our Barracks from Irregulars to Line Infantry. This will require us to acquire a large supply of Small Arms. - Research Napoleonic Warfare, and switch our artillery to Mobile Artillery. This means we need to fix our supply issues of Artillery. - Build up a proper army reserve. To do this, we will need to reform our archaic levy system and either acquire more people to conscript, or increase our conscription rate by abolishing Jizya.

OCR: Though the Janissaries have been disbanded, there is far more that must be done to modernize Our armed forces. Will complete if: Ottoman Army Reserves are greater or to 250 Ottoman Empire has researched Napoleonic Warfare All Ottoman Buildings: Currently, 144 fulfill this requirement At least one of these: Building is NOT Barracks All of these: Has NOT activated Irregular Infantry Has NOT activated Focus Has NOT activated Cannon Artillery equal Infantry

We currently have a single Arms Industry building, which is at level 3. Building up our domestic Arms Industry is going to be critical here, so my first move is to expand it and order the construction of a second Arms Industry in Rumelia

OCR: ARMs FnDUSTRIES Dresden in Bosnia Information Workforce Modifiers Yearly Productivity Employee Vienna #16 Arms Industries { 14.3 #181 in the world 721 Average Annual Employment: 15.0K Cash Reserves: 75.0K Auto-Expand Government Expenses: OOK Production Methods Et Process Weekly Balance: E+1.8SK {2.7K 46 { 4.9K 31 859 (E {2.8K 2.28K 60 Urbanization Infrastructure Centra Tlrouok Building - Vage Vages Usage

OCR: 0+3 Southern Sethia

Currently, 0 of our 144 levels of barracks are meeting the condition

This, however brings us to another problem. Our Construction Industry is... shall we say, inadequate.

OCR: 20.00 Construction 20/20 Pause Arms Industries 19.8 15w Arms Industries 0.1 30w eFaa Arms Industries Queued 45w Arms Industries Queued G0w Arms Industries Queued 75w Total time left: 75 weeks Ocnovsl ussia Bavaria

OCR: Construction Sector Thrace

I didn't want to put all my eggs into basket, but I also didn't want to spread it out too much due to economy of scale. Rumelia had a decent amount of free infra and qualifications.

OCR: MajorSkellyGeek Idag 16.29 @Martin Wiz" Anward Is there a reason why Rumelia specifically?

An important note about the fact that I am building industries: Our Arms Industries are currently run by traditional artisans rather than capitalists. We're going to keep it this way.

OCR: Ownership Production Method Current: Merchant Guilds Increased Employment: Shopkeepers: +1.50K Total Show per_Level values OOK Applies to Arms Industries (Ownership Production Method) Left-click to see available options" Et Process Weekly Balance: 2+1.86K Bavaria

On that note, let's look at our Interest Groups. The Landowners are currently in charge, with the Armed Forces and Sunni Madrasahs being powerful groups. This is just how we want to keep it, hence the need to avoid too many pesky Capitalist pops getting involved.

The Intelligentsia do not approve of our regime, but I don't approve of them right back.

OCR: 575 15.2% Social Criticism IG Traith 10.0% Prestige 13.7% Approval of Intelligentsia is Unhappy ( 5) or worse Intelligentsia NOT Marginalized People in power often think they are beyond reproach; but authority does not make someone's ideas interesting: We have lot of interesting to say; 9.60 and we know exactly Who to say them about: Unhappy ( 7) Marginalized Interest Groups things

Shopkeepers tend to join the Petit-Bourgeoise, which is significantly more socially conservative than the Industrialists, and hence an IG we can potentially work with.

OCR: OnionEater Idag 16.34 @Martin Wiz' Anward What's the significance of keeping the buildings ran by Shopkeepers? And what is the employment make up of the building Interest Groups that own it

We'll see. The most important thing is keeping the rabble suppressed, at any rate.

OCR: Jo (they/them) Idag 16.36 @Martin Wiz' Anward will you try to maintain an artisan economy that whole game? or will you have to accept capitalist pops at some point?

The Armed Forces are currently not huge fans of us, mainly because they think our traditional army is weakening their ability to fight wars. I happen to agree with this, so we're going to give them a chance to make some changes.

OCR: ent Laws Institutions Government Opposition Government Legitimacy 22.6% Sunni Madrasahs cals 4.39K Neutral (+1) lists 575 Armed Forces 15.2% Neutral ( 4) Approval The Armed Forces's Approval is Neutral (-4) 13.70 Foisie Active Laws Total Approval of is due to: Cevdet Ankuap of Armed Forces Approves of State Religion: (5) Armed Forces Disapproves of Peasant Levies: Armed Forces Disapproves of No Home Affairs: -1 9.6% Armed Forces Disapproves of No Police: .1 Armed Forces Approves of Censorship: Other Factors In Opposition: -1.00 from Commander Retirement Groups 1.00 from Leader Trait Persistent Unhappy Unhappy

We invite them into the government. This opens up an opportunity to reform our army model. This is actually quite a popular idea, many of the IGs approve of it either inherently or because of their leader's ideology. However, the Landowners oppose it, which is going to make it somewhat tricky to pass while they're in the government. We're certainly not going to take their Allah-given right to rule away however, so we'll just have to try and convince them.

OCR: Sultanate Government Sultan Government Legitimacy: 75% Mahmut Osmanoglu Radicals 4.39K Heir Apparent Loyalists 575 Local Governors 30.5% Happy Armed Forces 15.2% Neutral (-1) Laws Governmental or Movement support (16) with

Rural Folk are a bit weak in the current build. It's something we'll balance going forward.

OCR: Dictator Idag 16.42 0 @Martin Wiz" Anward Why rural folks aren't a thing here (marginalized IG)? (andrad)

The fact that Landowners are in government and oppose the change means it's going to be that much harder to pass, and might even fail, but we'll try it.

OCR: Overview Government Laws Stalled Enactment Chance The current Stalled Enactment chance is 30.5% due to: Base= 0.0% On next checkpoint on 21 July 1836, one of the following will From opposing Interest Groups: Success: 15.2% Local Governors: +30.5% Debate: 54.2% Stall: 30.5% Power Structure Economy nce Principles Economic System Free rchy Traditionalism Cer A

Back to building things and needing more Construction Sectors. Since Construction Sectors give a local boost to construction, I order one level each to be built in Bosnia and Rumelia and move them to the top of the queue. This will make all the other constructions I've ordered more efficient.

OCR: Belgrade Construction 20/20 Pause Construction Sector 18.0 Construction Sector 1.9 Sw Arms Industries Queued 20w Arms Industries Queued 33w Arms Industries Queued Arms Industries Queued 60w Arms Industries Queued 74w Total time left: 74 weeks

I would love to switch to a better construction method too, but we don't have the tech for that yet.

OCR: onstruction Sector Parma Base Wooden Buildings Florence Change Base Production Method to Iron-Frame Buildings Iron- Buildings X Country must have invented Urban Planning Predicted impact on Weekly Balance with full employment after Goods Substitution: 4.85K Steel- Buildings Unscaled Modifiers: +15.0% State Construction Efficiency Arc-Welded Buildings Total Modifiers: +20.0 Construction Goods Consumption: Tools: +20.0 more in Total 20.0 {20.0 in 3 States Fabric: -10.0 less in Total 20.9 {20.9 in 3 States Wood: -70.0 less in Total { 20.0 20.0 in 3 States tential Development Buildings Iron: +100 more in Total 44.6 446 in 3 States Increased Employment: Machinists: +1.00K more in Total Eiffel Statue of Decreased Employment: wet Big Ben Liberty Suez Canal Laborers or € Slaves: -1.OK less in Total Show per Level values Frame -Frame

Speaking of tech - we need Napoleonic Warfare, so I'm going to start working my way towards there. Ottomans should probably start with one or two more techs here tbh, but for now we'll just have to deal.

OCR: SGIekrLLUI Guntnidling Napoleonic Warfare Technology| Cost: 5.00K Innovation (23 months to research) Unlocks Unlocks Mobile Artillery for Barracks (Production Method) Unlocks Mobile Artillery for Conscription Center (Production Method) Leads to Field Works (Technology) Leads to Logistics (Technology) Requires all of the following: XLine Infantry Artillery Napoleon revolutionized warfare; emphasizing the importance of properly utilizing artillery: Start Researching ToC5J

I reformed the government to bring in the army, which has effects on Legitimacy. Adding more people to government generally isn't a problem, kicking them out however can create quite a few radicals if it's not viewed as legitimate.

OCR: huobaowhw Idag 16.45 @Martin Wiz' Anward So you just clicked button and the army joined the government?

So bringing in the army is easy, getting rid of them later might not be.

While waiting for my new constructions, I'm going to tackle some other inefficiencies. For one, our Tooling Workshops in Thrace are... not feeling well.

OCR: TOOLING JVORKSHOPS in Thrace Information Workforce Modifiers Yearly Productivity Employee Buch #21 Tooling Workshops { 0.0 #2724 in the world 47 Average Annual Employment: 20.0K Cash Reserves: 51.9K 10OK Auto-Expand Government Expenses: 0.OOK Production Methods E+ Process Weekly Balance: {-3.93K 190 3.8K { 3.7K 275 E5.SK (= 01.83K +80 Urbanization 8 Infrastructure Usage Building Vage Vages

The solution: Exports! France and Austria seem like they need our tools (or at least are getting them either way)

Sardinia-Piedmont is exporting our much-needed artillery. I am not happy about this as it's going to cause shortages for us, so I'm going to embargo Artillery. Embargoing means that we establish a protected share of our Artillery that can't be exported from our market, and costs Influence to maintain.

OCR: Import Route for Artillery Feb 7 Sardinia-Piedmont started an Import Route, moving 32 0 Artillery from the Turkish Market to the Piedmontian Market. eidl

I also embargo small arms while I'm at it. Ottomans guns are for Ottoman soldiers!

AAR : Korea - Korea by Daniel "neondt" Tolman

Currently playing as Korea. To clarify something I said earlier: tributary subjects do not automatically join your market in the current build.

Though I did voluntarily join the Chinese market, they have stuff that I want

Everything really. I don't need to worry about most of my basic needs and can focus on having a more specialized economy where I sell luxuries to rich Chinese pops

Of course that does put all my eggs into one basket and this will fail massively if China collapses (edited)

@Veers

Can I play too ?

Sure, just launch the secret steam app on the nightly build

@replacethelamp

cant you just join a better market

I'd have to find a large economic power that would want me in their customs union. Right now China is my only option, but I'm sure things will change later in the game

One advantage of China over anyone else though is the sheer quantities of basic resources they produce.

@Nils

Why would a country refuse you joining their market? My impression was the bigger my customs union the better

Yes and no. Sometimes a bigger market just means more mouths to feed

It's situational

You have more economic power but that comes with economic responsibility

Exactly

You ideally want countries in your customs union that either make someone you want, or want something you have

Absolutely. I'm currently doing that with luxury clothing

Being part of the Chinese market I have a huge amount of silk, so I'm using that to make luxury clothes and selling it back to China

Which also helps me industrialize and change the makeup of my pops

@replacethelamp

can you sell you luxury cloths to other markets even though you aren't the market leader

Nope, the market leader handles all foreign trade

@Nils

If I was china this would be the part where I would getting annoyed with you. You buying cheap and selling expensive, whats in for me

You get luxury clothes for your pops, saving you the trouble of diversifying your industry. You can use your money on developing something else that's more important to you.

It's symbiotic (edited)

You certainly could. And that would be great for me, because my clothes factories would become more profitable due to higher demand

@random person

why does AI china not produce expensive luxury clothes themselves if the nation has plenty of silk?

They certainly could. But they also have many, many other pop needs that they need to balance since they have millions of pops

Making luxury clothes isn't that high on the priority list

Compared to say, making sure there's enough rice for everyone to eat

@Dan

Daniel, I have a small modding question, is it possible for "consumption" of goods to do something like increase a variable? Like increase a pollution variable when pops consume diesel cars

Not sure. You could do it at the point of manufacture though

@One Proud Bavarian

Daniel, you should post some screenshots so that we can understand Korea's position better :))

I don't think I'm allowed

I'm just playing for fun. I do occasionally note things down that I might want to bring up at work on Monday though

I would really really like to avoid going to war in my Korea game. My military is pathetic; China and Japan would murder me in a heartbeat if they tried. That's why I'm happy to be a Chinese tributary

Should start thinking about maybe not being a feudal backwater. I'll establish a university

I don't think that I will

hmm.. could really use some currency standards too

Oh right I should also have schools. Guess I'll go with religious schools since the monks are very powerful and would support it

Right now I've got the Landowners and Monks

Oh right I forgot that I made philosopher-kings overpowered.

Should tone that down.

But for now I'll exploit it

@Hidra (She/Her)

It´s not that you were going to play Korea so you made it intentionally overpowered for your game

Nah any country that doesn't start out with a large university can get this

Currency standards acquired. Now I probably need to focus on production tech. Eventually I'll run out of infrastructure and will need trains, and I have a lot of tech to catch up on before I can get them

@Hidra (She/Her)

What is the most advanced tech you have?

I... know how to make steel. Korea is a little behind

@Miguelinileugim

What is the link to the 40GB file containing the alpha you're playing right now?

http://www.lasesp.com/article/1636195343240370/Victoria_3%20development%20build%20download

Daniel "neondt" Tolman

http://www.lasesp.com/article/1636195343240370/Victoria_3%20development%20build%20download

12 people clicked this. You know who you are and you should think about the choices you have made in your life that led you down this path

Universities are expensive

Perhaps I should tax grain..

aha I got schools! Thanks monks

Actually instead of taxing grain it would be more efficient to just directly increase taxes on the peasantry

There's not really any political will right now to reform the status of the peasantry

I eventually want to introduce an income tax but that will take time and will annoy people

@Nils

ram it through, for the good of the country Can you do it with negative costs or is it simply impossible

It would definitely cause a civil war at this point. Landowners like things the way they are and they are very powerful

Eventually industrialization will change the makeup of society such that landowners aren't so incredibly powerful, and then I'll be able to push through some less feudal reforms. But for now I'm stuck where I am on that front

Initially nobody. We'd important slaves. Unless we implemented debt slavery, in which case we'd enslave the poor

Which is kind of unnecessary since almost everyone is already a serf

My largest city is currently Pyongyang

Don't think there's a detailed GDP breakdown but my new luxury clothes and luxury furniture factories are the greatest contributors to the recent increases

If it's not in the slavery DD then I can't answer

Check the dev comments too, might be more info there

Alright I'm gonna take a risk, let's introduce a payroll tax

It occurs to me that my recent industrialization efforts have created a capitalist class that is fervently opposed to my taxation policy

They've created a Movement to oppose my law, but so far they're not TOO angry and they're only at 16% support

@Hidra (She/Her)

WHat is the biggest IG not currently in the government?

Monks. I kicked them out because I don't need them to enact my education reforms any more. Replaced them with the army, who support my tax reforms

Monks are fine with being kicked out of government, passing the law they liked made them very loyal

I kind of need to keep the landowners in government though, I just can't afford to annoy them and I'm never going to pass a law they approve of

@random person

how many chinese migrants are you getting as korea?

None, my borders are closed

I would like to open them one day but that is low on my priority list

@random person

assuming your pops are much richer than the chinese would it not mean a mass immigration would happen once you open them?

My pops are only slightly richer on average compared to the Chinese average. Oh and also my laws are super racist. Chinese pops are more likely to move to larger Chinese cities.

I want to expand my schools but I need bureaucracy, which is expensive

Really hope my tax laws pass

@Zombie_Freak115

Best move is enact super progressive rainbow laws like the flash and use the army to crush any disagreement and become the Beacon of progressivism and development in Asia

That will definitely not work

The guy who was writing my tax laws died

Petite Bourgeoisie have become pretty powerful. Considering changing my government to them and the Industrialists, then passing anti-feudalism laws

My tax law passed. I am.. now very wealthy

Time to totally reform society

@Miguelinileugim

Are there any downsides to taxing the elites and using the money to help the peasants

Yes. The elites will hate you and they typically have a lot of political power

With my new tax laws I can set taxes to minimum and still have a positive balance

@One Proud Bavarian

What is your relationship with China now? A tributary, certainly, but is there a tendency towards something?

Things are stable. Relations are good because I've been boosting them.

@Miguelinileugim

That seems a bit unbalanced

It's partially due to the fact that I don't have a lot of the expenses that more developed countries have. And I will want to take on those expenses to develop my economy and society. Tax income is nice but you really ought to be using it to grow your GDP and appease your pops (edited)

@Miguelinileugim

Sweet! Can you still run the economy in a market fashion by having low taxes and using pop money to fund expansion?

You certainly can, but that money can only be invested into certain things

Easy there, I still have less than 1/10 of China's GDP

I'm making ground on Japan though, almost at 1/2

@One Proud Bavarian

Excellent, excellent! We are still a monarchy, right? Daniel! Please tell me that our eternal right to rule is as true today as it was 100 years ago!

It is. Abolishing the monarchy would be a pretty bad idea right now. The monarchy is giving us much needed legitimacy to pass laws

Korea is not ready for democracy. Maybe in a decade

@One Proud Bavarian

The way Daniel is describing it, Korea sounds more like a second Siam rn than a second Japan

Yeah that's more or less how I'm playing this. Only thing that's missing is western powers taking an interest in what I'm doing

We are just BARELY, BARRELY below the threshold for a revolution

I'm abolishing serfdom. The landowners are angry

It occurs to me that this would be an excellent time to use my tax money to double military salaries. Just in case.

I want the generals on my side

I've also centralized the power of the armed forces in the capital and reduced their presence in the countryside where the landowners are powerful

YES serfdom is abolished

I think I should now not pass any more dangerous reforms for a little while

I could open up my economy. Nobody has strong feelings about transitioning from isolationism to agrarianism. It's not a big jump but it makes my tech spread less terrible

Or...

People would actually support Landed Voting (edited)

Actually no I want to keep the monarchy for now. Landed Voting could have unforeseen consequences

People might vote for things I don't like

@Captaincat

Hold up there was monarchy in Korea? The more you know

Yeah for like thousands of years

One consequence of abolishing serfdom: subsistence farms are now producing less grain due to not being forced to hand over their grain to the aristocracy. This has slightly increased food prices. Thankfully I'm in the Chinese market so this is barely noticable

@Fellington, Micro Knight

Wouldnt serfs leave the land when freed and go into urban areas

Yep. I expect that social mobility will increase. But I'm industrializing anyway so should have plenty of jobs for them

Will probably want to enact Poor Laws once the migration gets overwhelming though

I have a solution

@Paul "PDJR_Alastorn" Depre

@Captaincat

I have a question, is it possible for more traditionlist pops like aristocrats to maybe reform with education and become a leading reformist group?

Individual landowner leaders can be more or less traditionalist, but they're a fundamentally reactionary group

Ah the revolution is over. I won decisively, didn't even need China

After the revolution, the power of the landowners has been crushed. I now have the freedom to pass laws they will REALLY hate

Gonna start by replacing hereditary bureaucrats with appointed bureaucrats. Yay meritocracy.

It is time to build railways. I'm going to need... a lot of stuff. Coal, steel, motors. Nothing I can rely on China to make for me.

I need to build a lot of stuff fast. Will research a better construction PM. Which will increase the resources I need to construct stuff but I have money so it's fine

Prussia is winning

We're actually very pleased with the reception so far

We've got a much broader view of reception from multiple sources

@One Proud Bavarian

The funniest comment I have seen personally was about someone claiming the Vic3 devs have never played Vicky 2. Some people don't even seem to know who wiz is

I've been pretty open about the fact that I don't like V2. It had lots of cool ideas that were imo not executed well. Also the UI was incomprehensible.

But as I think people can tell, I'm enjoying V3 a lot

My railways are insanely profitable

My personal take on this is that the core gameplay loop is focused on the economic and political aspects of the game - intense military micro would be a distraction from that and would actively make the game less fun (edited)

My railway now runs all the way down my country and connects all my cities. There are little trains on the map chugging along. This is good.
