AAR : Russia - Russia by Daniel "neondt" Tolman

So, what's going on in Russia? Tsar Nikolai Romanov rules over a largely pre-industrial peasant society. He rules with an iron fist, the monarchy backed up by repressive laws like Autocracy, Censorship, and Serfdom

The economy is... functional. We're not running a deficit by default. IT's mostly based on peasant agriculture, supervised by the aristocracy. The government's budget comes almost entirely (around 80%) from taxes specifically on the peasantry

Though we're also getting a good amount of money from a consumption tax on liquor

@JoJo (Stellaris QA Lead)

Whats our demographics?

Around half the population is Russian, with Poles, Ukrainians and Belorussians making up the largest minorities. Of these, we discriminate against Poles, as well as nearly all of the many other minorities in Russia (edited)

The overwhelming majority of people follow the Russian Orthodox Church

@Balkan Devastation Enjoyer

any minorities we don't discriminate against yet?

Ukrainians and Belorussians

We have a significant (maybe 10%) Catholics minority, as well as a few Muslims of various schools and a smattering of Protestants

Political power from pops (disregarding other factors) is firmly in the hands of the aristocrats.

@Wesh

Do you discriminate against a Culture or a Religion separately or you can choose to only target Catholic Poles for example (combination of culture+religion)?

They're separate. But we enforce a State Religion, so non-Orthodox pops are discriminated against. It is not a good time to be a Catholic Pole

Overall, the poor are barely able to feed themselves while the rich live relatively luxurious lives. We're going to widen that gap even further - our goal today is human misery

@Tripledot

how are the tatars doing?

Not great. They're discriminated against

The diplomatic situation is undeveloped. We have a Personal Union with Finland, which is in our Market. Greece owes us a Favor. Britain is our Rival

We probably want to make a friend. As an opening move, I'm going to propose an alliance with fellow reactionary monarchy, Austria

Let's take a look at the internal political situation..

The government is made up exclusively of the landowning aristocracy

They are powerful and enjoy the full backing of the Tsar

The Orthodox Church is also powerful, but not part of the government. They are fairly neutral towards the government, leaning positive. I want to make them loyal, and I have some ideas about how to achieve that

There's also a significant but not yet powerful capitalist industrial class. They're also neutral, but leaning negative. I have mixed feelings about these guys. They might be useful, but they might also be a thorn in our side (edited)

I have no intention of allowing free trade

@kebb

how are the nascent intelligensia?

hahahaha. Marginalized. Actively. We pour a lot of our authority into keeping them that way.

Liberalism is not tolerated in Russia

Here's something that I find VERY concerning. The armed forces are decently strong, but they seem to really despise the government. This is a big problem. We need their loyalty.

@MingorSolum

Just pay them. Alot. (edited)

Well it turns out that one of the reasons for their disloyalty is our low military wages.

@Balkan Devastation Enjoyer

we're not running a deficit right? increase their wages and go into a deficit. Nothing bad can come out of this

I've increased their wages t othe point that they're getting no penalties or bonuses from them. This took up 1/3 of our remaining budget

They're still unhappy but at least not actively disloyal. We'll need to pass some laws that they like (edited)

@Balkan Devastation Enjoyer

what laws do they like

Well we could ramp up the censorship, institute police or national guard, introduce new conscription laws..

I think I'm going to start out by trying to pass a law called Outlawed Dissent. It's like Censorship but MORE. All of the important interest groups approve of this - the landowners, the church, and the military. The rest either don't care or they're so marginalized that I don't care about their objections

The best part is that when the law passes, their objections will be even more irrelevant

We're starting out with a 37% chance to pass the law on the enactment timer, and an extremely high chance of advancing its progress even if it doesn't pass first time

@Balkan Devastation Enjoyer

good, we're running a perfect government already

That is actually what inspired this playthrough

@Illusive_S

whats the timer? days? weeks? months?

It's January, and we'll next see a result in August

Daniel "neondt" Tolman

It's January, and we'll next see a result in August

This is a relatively short time, because it's a law supported by most relevant aspects of society (edited)

@MingorSolum

Daniel how is the world looking right now? Any major crises or is the world peaceful

I've barely unpaused

I should also start building things and deciding where to focus my tech. I don't currently have the required tech for police, so that seems like a good start. And when I get that tech I'll need a lot of bureaucracy to run my police forces. So I should build Government Administrations

@PanShot

Where does tech even come from?

Having Universities helps. But the downside of that is that you have more annoying students who want "rights" and "equality" and such

I've noticed that there is an immense demand for Fish. I will focus the entire economy of the Baltic states towards producing fish

We could alos use more Tools. Mazovia has a tooling workshop. I guess I'll expand it

And on the topic of widening the wealth gap - our poor aristocrats are struggling to buy luxurious silk outfits. The price of luxury clothes is far too high. I could either import them, or start producing them myself. Let's see if I have any source of silk..

@Dan

@Daniel "neondt" Tolman Do you start the game with any railways?

Russia does not appear to have any railways

Alright, switching my textile mills to luxury clothes is a terrible idea. We have no silk

I suppose I'll import some

hmm.. for various reasons (we haven't really talked about trade so I'll gloss over this), I'm struggling to import any silk

I can't make silk myself, nor can I import it. This leaves only one option: importing the clothes directly. It would be better to import raw materials and manufacture them myself because it's good for the economy. But alas that's not an option in this case

@Dan

@Daniel "neondt" Tolman How is market access in this situation? Are states forced to be relatively self supporting?

Things seem fine for now. Lack of industrialization means little need for infrastructure

Having now established the import of 450 luxury clothes from Great Britain, the price of these goods as dropped significantly. Finally the poor archdukes can afford a silk coat!

We should hopefully see the Standard of Living for upper-class pops increase as a result. And since they're richer, they have more political clout, reinforcing the political balance of power that I want

There's also a desire for meat and fabric. I'm more concerned about the high price of fabric because it's a building material that the government has to buy in order to construct things

You know where I can get both meat and fabric? Sheep

The steppe around Astrakhan has some livestock ranches. I'll improve those

Ah I can also grow Cotton in the Caucasus. So I shall

Maybe exclusively growing cash crops in that region will come back to bite me some day. But that's a problem for future Russia

As a result of all this construction, we're now running a small deficit. It's not enough that I'm going to institute any additional taxes yet. I'll need that later, but for now I'm just spending money to make money

@Doodlez - Fotp

Construction is also a jobs program so we are good on another front too

Most people are subsistence farmers, so unemployment isn't really an issue for Russia

hmm, even with my consumption taxes and suppressing the intelligentsia, I have plenty of Authority to spare. Tempted to leave it unspent, since having more than you need speeds up law enactment time

And I do want my Outlawed Dissent

Russian government: the price of tools is a bit high, let's make more Prussian government: Let's import tools from Russia

@Doodlez - Fotp

That is good for Russia coin right?

My tooling workshops will be more profitable, but I don't care about their profitability. I want them to make cheap tools for my construction

It's not like I care about the people working in these factories.

@PENAPENA

Is there a way to cut off trading a particular item?

I have no ability to embargo or discourage goods. My economic laws are really backwards

@Hokki

But think of the children Daniel!

I am thinking of the children!

OCR: Children'$ Rights Child Labor Allowed

You know what, maybe switching to a different economic model might be good. I'm currently using Traditionalism, which is bureaucratically cheap but is otherwise just bad. Agrarianism would give me an Investment Pool from the Aristocrats, and give me a lot more economic options

But that'll have to wait, currently too busy with ultra-censorship (edited)

@PENAPENA

Is there support for Agrarianism?

There is! It would be widely supported by the aristocracy and the peasantry alike

Even the Industrialists see it as an improvement over not having an economic system at all

@Doodlez - Fotp

Getting money from Aristocrats for investments sounds like a better way rather than taxing them outright.

Absolutely. Taxing the rich is not on my agenda today

Instead they're free to exploit their serfs to their heart's content, so they'll invest in more farms to exploit more serfs!

@liberty90

@Daniel "neondt" Tolman So for now there was no investment pool?

Indeed. All expansion is at the government's expense (edited)

@liberty90

Would agrarianism prohibit using gov treasury for econ expansion?

Yeah I'd be mostly limited to using the money on agriculture

@Jüstinyen

How industrialized are you rn? Is there at least 1 factory in every state?

Have you seen Siberia?

@Doodlez - Fotp

The investment pool money that is right?

Yes. I can still spend government funds on whatever I want

Decided to check on the price of iron. It's fine. But could be more fine. A few more mines would be nice

I'll mine in the Urals

Russia surprisingly has some fairly large urban centers. But that urbanization is not coming from factories. It is almost entirely from military buildings

I've declared an Interest in the Balkans, Manchuria, and Japan (I'm going to want Sakhalin)

We are also VERY slowly colonizing Kazakhstan

I could speed it up but I can't afford the bureaucratic expense. Besides we want to use that on Police

@Dan

Other than Divine Right why do you want Sakhalin?

It's got a bit of everything. Iron, coal, whales, fish, and wood

Of course we're barely even exploiting the riches of Siberia yet

We have an immense reserve of completely untapped resources

Oh something is happening

Austria has started a Diplomatic Play against Prussia. They want Silesia

Austria has a much stronger military, and honestly I would prefer the balance of power in Germany to stay the same. But as Austria's ally I am not able to take Prussia's side

My leaning here is to Declare Neutrality on this issue

The Ottomans, presumably for similar reasons, are leaning towards Prussia

@Ulf "UlfDerDritte" III

wouldn't it be a good idea to weaken Prussia, since it has a lot of potential untapped at the start?

It has potential. But Austria is currently dominant.

@Illusive_S

i imagine if you declare participation in diplo play and it blows up into a full scale war, you are instantly a participant?

Exactly!

The deficit is a bit more significant now, since I'm also investing in the lumber industry a bit, for the same reasons that I'm building Iron mines. I want to lower the cost of construction. Still not quite enough that I'll institute new taxes

@Ulf "UlfDerDritte" III

tbf, he doesn't like that Prussia is buying the tools

Exactly. Prussia buying my tools means they're more expense for my government to buy

The Ottomans have officially join Prussia's side. This just slightly tips the odds in Prussia's favor

Prussia has some interesting goals. They want to conquer parts of Poland, and in the process liberate the city of Krakow

If Krakow gets liberated I might just... eat it up

Prussia why. Groceries are quite expensive in Russia and they just opened new imports. I wonder if Prussia is deliberately doing this...

Can't tell if AI is waging economic warfare or just determined that I'm a good source of food for some reason

Prussia is very wary of us

@Dan

To do this, would Prussia's grocery prices be even higher than Russias?

Quite possibly. Looking at their market, they now have cheap groceries. Presumably because they're stealing mine.

Just in case I'm going to start damaging relations with Prussia

If they actually win against Austria they'll be quite powerful

Outlawed Dissent did not pass immediately. But the Petite Bourgeoisie have decided that they really love this law, increasing the chance of it passing next time

Oh dear, it's escalating into a war

I'm hoping for a bloody stalemate where nobody really wins

@Ezno

Yes.

@Bruno Carvalho

Have you backed someone?

I Declared Neutrality, which blocks me from ever interfering military in this play

Maybe if someone is winning too hard I could open an export route for guns..

@MingorSolum

what do the rest of the Europeans think about this?

Both sides have made outrageous demands, increasing their infamy. They're not getting involved but they are not going to be happy if either side manages to win decisively

Since I'm looking at the diplomatic situation, I noticed that neighboring Moldavia in an Ottoman Protectorate, but not economically tied to them. They have their own market, and it is small and not performing well. They would join our customs unions if we offered.

@EditedDruid

What can they bring to the market?

Nothing of value. They're peasant farmers like us

I think I'll leave them to their squalor

(I say squalor but their SoL is higher than most of Russia, partially due to being less massively repressive)

Moldavia did just start buying our Clothes. Just regular clothes, not luxury clothes. I have no strong opinion about this.

Surprisingly, Saxony (a minor non-negotiating participant in the war) has occupied Bohemia

While Austria has occupied Bosnia

That's sure to go well

oh no. game crashed

This is the hottest of hot code. Build is from yesterday

AAR : Schaumburg-Lippe - Schaumburg-Lippe by Martin "Wiz" Anward

So Schamburg-Lippe is the smallest and most pathetic nation in Europe, with a population of 23.8k and a GDP of 6.55k. As a way of comparison, Luxemburg (not exactly a powerhouse) has a population of 175k and a GDP of 181k.

And yes, that's a GDP just short of 7 thousand

I have a single-province state in Westphalia with 6 arable land (actually should be less, but in this branch they're slightly overpowered) and a little bit of potential for coal, iron, wood and sulfur

It's not all bad though. I do have a few things going for me: A decent literacy rate at 51.3% and (crucial to my strategy) the Ruhr Coalfields State Trait, which boosts coal production by 10%

Now, we only have potential for 2 levels of coal mines, but as my workforce amounts to just above 5k (enough for a single level of building) that's good enough

Hence, my plan is to turn all of Schaumburg-Lippe into a coal mine supplying the Prussian Market

My first move is to ask big papa Prussia if I can be their Protectorate, because I certainly won't be doing any protecting myself

They say yes, which is nice. Being a Protectorate means I'm a subject, but a very autonomous one. I don't pay any tribute, I don't have to be part of their market (I want to though) and I just give up some diplomatic independence. So long as they maintain a nice attitude towards me and don't want to make me a Puppet, this is great.

@Deleted User

Will they accept though? Is there any case under which the AI might reject protectorate request?

Sure, depending on their attitude they might want nothing to do with you

There is one other advantage to me being so pathetic: With so few people to administrate, I have a pretty decent surplus of bureaucracy just from the base capacity generated by my nation. I start growing my police institution, just in case my coal miners ever start getting ideas.

Speaking of which, I've started construction of a single level of coal mines and research into water-tube boiler (which will improve the efficiency of said mine)

@BOBA THICC

How are the interest groups looking?

Well really, the landowners and church are the only ones of any significance

That'll change once we get going in the coal mining business though

@Deleted User

So it’s just a way for you to be turned into a puppet in the future

Not necessarily. The AI might decide it's not worth the trouble of reigning in my autonomy. I'm banking on this really.

@General_WCJ

So. What happens when Prussia forms something bigger?

If Prussia forms something bigger and I'm still their subject, I get absorbed into that something. So let's hope that doesn't happen.

My cousins in Lippe apparently think that family feuds are all the rage, as they just declared themselves my rival

well whatever, they can take it up with Prussia

I start improving relations with both Prussia and Austria, never hurts to suck up to the big boys

I also issue a decree to encourage resource industries, which will help once my little mine is up and running

and another decree to attract migrants, though the prospects of that aren't too great at the moment, given our low standard of living

Funny you should mention that, I've already tapped out my gold reserve and am now taking loans

but I'm confident I can pay those off down the line

@Thorius

Dont you start out with any production beyond sustinence?

Nope, no starting buildings at all

And pretty much my entire income is from minting coins with my chubby count on htem

Subsistence farms

Since those appear anywhere with unused arable land

Fascinatingly, my strategy to appear migrants is actually working! I have a small trickle of sorbs moving in from Saxony, it seems

and immediately, my newspapers start printing articles blaming the Sorbs for everything

I have an education institution at level 2

(The newspaper thing is an event)

I decide to suppress the article since honestly I need whatever immigration I can get

Well, not a month passed and my projected migration is back in the red

It was nice while it lasted

I guess I should've been paying a bit more attention to my radicals. It seems that the wages I pay to construction workers is basically so low they'd have a better life as subsistence farmers, and the people I drafted to build my coal mines are miffed about this

Well, nothing for it, keep building those coal mines

it'll all get better at some point

This is also why my migration attraction tanked

radicals are causing turmoil

I'm still up 500 people from when I started though

Police helps mitigate penalties from turmoil, so I'm going to keep expanding that institution

My coal mines are done!

Now they just need to hire people to work there

I'm going to subsidize them to speed up the process, as this isn't just a vital industry, it's our only industry

We currently lack enough qualifications to fully staff the coal mine, but even running at half capacity, it's made our GDP jump several times over

I'm going to invest in more education

so I can teach the aristocrats to be mine owners instead

I guess they need to go to mine owner school or something

Currently, 9k out of 24.1k people in Schaumburg-Lippe are radicals

This isn't... great

I have 43 loyalists though!

Also, the price of coal is very high in the Prussian market right no

w

so the mine is doing quite well

Unfortunately the mine owners are hogging most of that money for themselves and paying peanut wages right now

but at least SoL should rise a little from the days of forced construction work

Sure, let me just ask my interest groups

Turns out they all say no

It isn't even like the regular people are demanding that or anything, they're just angry peasants forced to build and work in a coal mine

I'd have to spend quite a bit of time nurturing class conciousness if I want a welfare state

I do have quite a bit of authority to throw at my one state since my country is so tiny and reactionary though

so I issue a decree to force slightly improved conditions for the poor

it isn't quite 'nobody starves', more like 'nobody super-starves'

our population is back down to 23.8k because of emigration

I'm shedding people like crazy due to this turmoil

Apparently they are going to Brandenburg, Mecklenburg... and Thüringia

I'm not generating extra SoL per se

Just forcing certain minimums

Oh boy, there's a war

France vs Britain, Spain, Netherlands and a lot of other people

Apparently France is trying to puppet Spain (the AI is very aggressive in the current build, this is going to be revised down the line)

France has lost half a million people so far

this was perhaps not the best thing they've ever done

Well, on the bright side, we're down to just 4k radicals!

And our standard of living is back above starving

I call this intense progress

I do kind of hope Prussia gets into a bad war tbh

as that could mean lots of migrants for me

just so long as I don't get invaded

I need to AFK briefly, then I will show you my country panel (not going to screenshot other than that though)

I return, and I bring with me the Coal Mining Miracle

OCR: SCHAUMBURG_-LIPPE Country Information Modifiers Diplomacy 94 GDP { 1OOK Population 23.7K Literacy 54.9% Standard of Living Struggling .46) State Religion Protestant Government: Duchy Cultures North German Arable Land 6.696 2.0%6 Infamy Reputable Primary

We may have a lower population than when we started, but check that GDP

Prussia is desperate for coal, and we're in the business of coal

the industrialists have suddenly become the most powerful IG, after aristocrats saw the mad money in coal mining and deserted their estates

well there's actually still more aristocrats than capitalists

but the capitalists are just that much richer

AAR : Papal States - Pt.1 - by Daniel "neondt" Tolman

Today we're playing PRESTIGIOUS POPE

We're gonna become a great power through the power of ART

Balance and AI are very not final, so I really can't say if this will be viable in the final game. Haven't done this in a while so actually not sure if it's viable now, but we're gonna try

So, the Papal States. We are, shockingly, an autocratic theocracy with very conservative laws. We accept both Italian cultures and there are no significant minorities in the country, either cultural or religious. There is a small Jewish population but it's unlikely to ever be politically relevant.

Taking a look at our economy, it is very definitely pre-industrial. There's a lot of work to be done.

Art academies are expensive and we're not going to be able to afford them with our tiny economy that raises most of its money through taxes on the peasantry

We're currently 2.9k in the green. Max peasant taxes would only give us another 2k

I don't think peasant taxes are the way to go.

We have our own market. Certain luxury goods are very expensive but for the most part people have what they need

We do have a shortage of Clippers though. I'll just buy them

@Velstrom

Nah, fund those clipper factories. They should still be relevant in a fewd decades

I'll definitely want to become self-sufficient in the shipbuilding industry later, but I don't think it's gonna be my first move

@Captaincat

can the papacy form italy?

Yes!

I think the first law we're going to want to pass is Religious Schools. We want more Literacy, so people will be qualified more the more specialized jobs we'll need going forward. I would ideally like to reform my tax laws but there's just no support for it right now

To support these schools I'll need a lot of Bureaucracy, so I'll build Government Administrations in Rome

I took a look at my fisheries

They were using the Simple Fishing PM, but since we've just started importing Clippers and we're buying more than we need, I've switched them over to Fishing Trawlers

This has quite substantially reduced the price of fish, since we're producing a lot more

This is basically a good thing, because fish was really quite expensive before

The profitability of the buildings is about the same. The price of their outputs is lower and the cost of their inputs is higher, but the increased output makes up for it.

Oddly enough there's also a significant demand for wine

So I guess my opening moves will be to provide the miracle of fish and wine

Oh I see why demand for wine is so high

OCR: Obsessions: Wine

I'll expand the wheat farms in Romagna, which are using the Vineyards PM

With all this construction, wood is getting kind of expensive. I'll start a logging industry in Umbria

We're now in a deficit, but I'm not too concerned

Oh hey our fisheries just got more profitable. Egypt is now buying our fish.

Meat is also expensive, and I could potentially solve that by using Butchering Tools in my Livestock Ranches. But this would cause an input shortage of Tools, so I'll need to wait until I get Tools Workshops going.

Or I guess I could import Tools for now. Might as well.

@Brad

how easy is this info found? at the point of making the decision?

You can get an overview of your market in the market view, or you can see more details about particular industries in the building panel

Alright I've imported Tools, so I switched everything over to Butchering Tools. This still left us with with a lot of tools, so I switched my Logging Camps in Lazio over to Sawmills, which reduced the price of wood and therefore the state's construction expenses (edited)

Main market issues now are the high prices of glass and fabric. These will be solvable later, for now I'll live with it

I'm researching Lathe for now, since it's on the way towards Railways which are universally useful. If I had a lot of Universities I'd instead be rushing art techs

@CaptainChiffre

Yeah it's a pop need rather than a building need. Also the high price of glass in my market is mostly due to French and Sicilian export routes. This makes my glass industry very profitable but my pops are struggling to afford glass.

We could really use some more money... tempted to impose a consumption tax

I'm gonna take the risk - I'm taxing grain

The budget is now almost exactly balanced

And I can increase this tax if needed

Romagna has expanded its vineyards. I think the next thing I want to do there is expand the Textile Mills. This is an urban building which employs Shopkeepers and Laborers, which shifts pops to IG's I'd prefer better than farms. Clothes are also quite expensive.

In Umbria I'm actually going to go in the opposite direction and build a Cotton Plantation. Always need more Fabric and as a relatively small nation we have the capacity to be self-sufficient

It's treated like an autocracy, so a new leader is generated at random

Umbria's new Logging Camps are doing a lot of work. Price of wood is now quite reasonable

They also employ Capitalists, which is nice

The Industrialist IG is not get relevant in the country, but some day it will be

Our economic laws are... really bad. Traditionalism, levying, no income taxes...

I really want to enact an Income Tax law, but I'm blocked by having Traditionalism. I don't have 10 years to try to pass both laws, the economy can't survive the wait. Instead I have to take the next best option - replace Levying with a Per Capita tax. It won't bring anywhere near as much revenue as an Income Tax, but it'll balance the budget.

PRESTIGIOUS POPE continues here

I've played a little more without updating so here's a quick summary: With our increase in power rank and continued efforts to improve relations, Tuscany has finally agreed to enter our Customs Union. Their economy is much more developed than the minor countries currently in our market - they produce a lot of clothes, including luxury clothes as they have their own Silk Plantations. They also bring with them a hugely better source of Iron, as well as yet more potential for Sulphur mining. They even have their own University. I have continued to expand our Arts Academies, to the point that the national budget can barely afford the cost even with our new Per Capita Tax laws. I did this to pursue a [REDACTED] that made Rome the center of the Realist Movement, greatly improving the throughput of the Academies and therefore our Prestige

@Bioiron

They aren't in favour of slavery, it's more that they haven't gotten around to abolishing it yet

Nuance is overrated, meme is funny

@wilcoxchar

there are only two factories in Victoria games, luxury furniture and clipper ships

There is also opium

@Engram, the Fennoman

inb4 an AnCap mod which makes it the best system of government

We don't represent anarcho-capitalism in V3, only normal anarchism.

You can prevent movements from becoming radical enough to cause problems by not having radicals. Keep SoL high.

I mean, it's a very strategic game and thinking ahead to prevent problems before they happen is a lot more effective than trying to deal with a problem after it surfaces

@Nils

So panem et circensis is still a valid strategy?

Yes, though you can think of it in less cynical terms. If SoL is high, your system of government is actually working out for a lot of people and they won't be politically radicalized

@Nils

is it easier to get a high SoL when you are more liberal or could I manage to stay the supreme autocrat of all russians without any parliament and all if I have enough ressources for the SoL?

Yes, but the process of achieving that economically is likely to empower people who will be inherently opposed to your regime

Early game autocracies can get a lot done, and can really get the ball rolling in terms of modernization. But later that modernization will create the means that overthrow the autocracy.

You can mitigate that limit with repression and brute force

Yeah that's basically how you have to run an autocracy as the game progresses

@Nils

I might have got it wrong but I understood Daniel that way that a high SoL will allow my pops to think for themself which might end up in weird ideas that will result in radicals when I say no to those ideas

It more that wealth contributes to political strength, and different types of pops will gravitate to different IG's, and as lower stratas gain some measure of wealth they will empower IG's that will oppose autocracy

@Brad

How can I go about Chinese style state capitalism?

Mercantilism and Outlawed Dissent

Yeah you can get Movements with or without radicals. A movement with very few radicals is toothless, unless you actually WANT the law they're proposing in which case you can leverage their support to get the law passed faster.

@Nils

So if I want a different outcome I might get it by brutally opressing the very IG which idea I like in order for them to overthrow me

I would really like to do an "accelerationist" run where I deliberately make things as bad as possible in the hopes that people will rise up against me and enact rapid reforms. That was part of what I wanted to do with the Russia AAR but it was cut short by a crash.

I'm no AI programmer (or AI designer for that matter), so I'm not the best person to ask about this. I guess one massive difference compared to other PDS games is that the AI is not concerned with military micro, because it doesn't exist.

@Bioiron

Definitely a combination of factors, but I wasn't able to identify them. It can actually be quite fun to try to work out why something is happening though.

Absolutely. The industrialists are chiefly concerned with passing laws that enrich capitalists rather than the whole population, for example

Perhaps one is even brewing where I left things

No sure how you'd achieve that. Goods would have to be insanely cheap, but for that to be the case the people making them would have terrible wages.

They're not abnormally powerful, the USA is just incredibly weak due to a devastating civil war. The war ravaged the mid-west in particular.

@s p i c e

Would becoming a tax haven actually be a viable strategy for massive waves of immigration?

Low taxes are one way of improving your SoL, so sure that can attract migrants.

@NEF

Dividend taxes perhaps? It’s a curious question. How do we fund all this? Maybe focus on producing an expensive good in Krakow that many people want?

The problem for Krakow is that they have nothing that can't be produced cheaper by someone else.

And they're locked into the Austrian market at the start

Japan can become very wealthy if you plan ahead well enough.

Another of the many interesting things about Japan is that luxury goods industries don't have export value, since you can't trade. So you've got all of this silk and probably some luxury industries, and hardly anyone to sell it to

Daniel "neondt" Tolman

Another of the many interesting things about Japan is that luxury goods industries don't have export value, since you can't trade. So you've got all of this silk and probably some luxury industries, and hardly anyone to sell it to

This means it's trivially easy to meet the needs of the upper strata, for the most part

But it also means that industries that would be big money makers in other countries aren't going to be very profitable in isolationist Japan

I think later on as Japan, I'd want to switch over to a Mercantilist economic policy. This would allow me to sell luxuries to other countries, and buy goods that I just can't produce in Japan like rubber and oil, whilst also keeping the economy relatively closed off through lots of embargoes (e.g. you can buy my luxury clothes but not my silk)

@s p i c e

Are planned economies going to have to get carpal tunnel building infrastructure and railroads again?

No more than any other economic policy. Buildings and infrastructure are always player-directed

@Thorius

Wouldn't Japan be VERY dependent on its Merchant Navy, since it will later have to import lots of raw materials and food?

I don't think it'll need a lot of food imports, Japan has a good amount of agricultural potential. Enough to feed itself at any rate. But if you're importing rubber and oil, those things are by that point critical to your economy, so yes you'll want to protect your trade

@Bioiron

ok, here is something I need to know, under free trade, do you pay for, like, tool workshop contruction with government money, investment pool money, or both?

It comes from the investment pool and building cash reserves if those things are available, and the remainder comes from the government

@Thorius

Yes Rubber and Oil, but isnt Japan also dependent on Importing Metal ores? I only remember them having decent Coal deposits, but their Iron ore famously was not that good (Which is the main reason by they used folding for their blades)

Their iron deposits are far from inexhaustible, but I haven't personally experienced an iron shortage as Japan. My PM's have been able to keep up with demand thus far, but I haven't played into late game with them.

@Avian Overlord

If you can tell me, how much can you mix ownership forms?

Depends on your laws and techs

As Japan I strategically research production techs that unlock better PM's for raw materials so I can squeeze every last bit of productivity. Raw materials are the one thing you can't just endlessly build more of.

Daniel "neondt" Tolman

As Japan I strategically research production techs that unlock better PM's for raw materials so I can squeeze every last bit of productivity. Raw materials are the one thing you can't just endlessly build more of.

I almost get a bit of a Frostpunk vibe from this kind of gameplay, weighing up my current needs vs my future needs when it comes to tech decisions. Opportunity cost is such a huge factor in V3.

Whenever you do something in V3, you are not doing something else.

None

AAR : Papal States - Pt.3 - by Daniel "neondt" Tolman

It's once again PRESTIGIOUS POPE time

Quick recap from last time: we've unified central Italy plus Lombardia, we have some semblance of a national budget despite our awful economic laws, and the world is generally on fire

Today's goal: Risorgimento. We're going to build an actual army and use it to unify all of Italy

As I noted yesterday, our integration of Lombardia gave us access to a very impressive Arms Industry, which produces cheap Artillery and Small Arms

@General_WCJ

All? I thought you were fine with partial reunification?

I was, but then I achieved all my other goals

Looking at our Barracks in Rome, we're not using the most up to date production methods available.

So I've switched from Line Infantry to Skirmish Infantry, which require the additional good Ammunition as well as a greater proportion of Officers in the ranks

I don't currently produce Ammunition, but we don't need much so I've opened an Import route from France

@HideousPillow

Do we still only have 5 battalions?

After annexing more of Italy, we're now up to 35

I've also moved us over from Infantry Focus to Mobile Artillery. So we're now actually using cannons. This PM also inputs Tools, which is not ideal because tools are much more expensive than our super cheap military goods.

And in Barracks, the government has to buy all of the input goods and pay all employee wages

Armies, like art, are expensive

@Thorius

How big is the City of Rome ?

Its Urban Center is size 10. Compare to Paris at 15, and London at 50.

Typically Paris would be bigger by now, but AI France is having a bad day

@Captain "Power BI" Nemo

But prestigious?

Armies are also prestigious! But much less so than art

@Thorius

Whats the correlation between Urban centre Size and Population?

There is none, urbanization comes from urban buildings. You could have millions of people in a state but no urban center at all.

No, one per state

Btw, Milan and Florence are both larger cities than Rome. both at size 12

Daniel "neondt" Tolman

Btw, Milan and Florence are both larger cities than Rome. both at size 12

So we've very substantially increased our urban population by integrating central Italy

Daniel "neondt" Tolman

So we've very substantially increased our urban population by integrating central Italy

And of course this greatly affects the internal balance of power. Landowners are increasingly irrelevant, while the Petite Bourgeoise, Industrialists, and Intelligentsia are highly relevant

Updating our Production Methods has had a huge impact on the budget. Between salaries and military goods, we're down £10k

(salaries are higher because we're now paying more Officers instead of regular Soldiers) (edited)

@Brad

deficit spending is fine

Thankfully we're still in the green, there's no deficit yet and we still have a small gold reserve

Taking a look at our military tech, things aren't great. Tech spread has generously given us a couple of tier 2 navy techs for our mighty armada of zero ships

We haven't focused on a single military tech the whole game

Our only tier 2 army tech is Logistics, which is actually a very important once because that unlocked Skirmish Infantry.

Right now I'm going to shift my research over to Percussion Caps. This will unlock Munitions Plants, so I can make my own ammo, and it'll also unlock Shrapnel Artillery for my Barracks.

I'll also expand my Barracks in Rome to allow another 5 battalions

@DrawElements

Is SSM allowed in Vic3 or is it like CK3?

V3 doesn't have any representation of marriage at all.

My GDP is £15m

@Nuukov

How did France joining ruin it? I wonder when it comes to playing the game, what helps you make an informed decision on who to let into your market.

You can quite easily look at other country's markets and see what they're consuming and producing, and compare that to your own market. If you think they're a good match, a customs union might be favourable. (edited)

I accepted France into my market without much thought because I wasn't intending on continuing the game for much longer anyway

@Mitros

Are markets still state based? or even if you have 2 countries in one state each get their own market? (i thought it was due for change?)

A state region can only have 1 market. This is determined by which country has the largest state in the state region.

@The_Last.Satrap

I mean, can't I irritate Irish Catholics enough to make them force me go catholic ?

Irish Catholics don't want Britain to adopt Catholicism. They want Ireland to not be part of Britain.

@Skellius9(An-Staf-Wor-ism)

can a country be in different markets at once?

Some of your states might not be in your national market if they're split states and another country has a larger state in that region

There was never a time when I was happy with the Papal economy, our laws were really bad and I wasn't able to reform them to any great extent. I just barely made things work with what I had.

It probably would have been better to put real effort into industrializing and building an economic base, which would have promoted the IG's I needed to do faster reforms. But instead I rushed Arts Academies.

Not really, I was a paper tiger. I did it because it was cool, not because it helped me

I didn't even have an army until after I became a GP

@THE Skelly

This is definitely true. You definitely can force it through art spam like I did, but being a GP in name only is not hugely beneficial. I was still economically and militarily weak.

@One Proud Bavarian

So then, what benefits do Rank confer? Generally, the higher a country’s Rank, the more Influence capacity it generates (allowing for a greater freedom in conducting diplomacy and signing diplomatic pacts), the more Declared Interests it can support (more on that next week) and the more Maneuvers it has in Diplomatic Plays (more on that in a few weeks). Rank also plays a key role in many other systems such as Subjects, Infamy, Diplomatic Actions and more, some of which we’ll get into in the coming weeks (I know I keep saying that, but bear with me, we’ve only just started on Diplomacy!).

It was certainly nice to be able to maintain improved relations with all of the Italians I wanted to integrate as well as the Great Powers who might make things difficult for me

Bordering Russia is not a chill game

Korea was very chill. Japan is maximum chill.

@EnglishMobster

Was Vicky ever restored as the Queen, btw?

No, deposed monarchs are cast into the void never to return

@Skellius9(An-Staf-Wor-ism)

is that possible in vic3?

Probably?

@Concerned_doggo

I thought that stockpiles are still going to be in vic3

No stockpiles

Having played the game a lot I don't really see any need for stockpiling. The price model is extremely robust.

One thing I like about the price system is that it's essentially self-balancing. Stockpiles would throw a real spanner into the works.

Cash reserves are not a goods stockpile

@Skellius9(An-Staf-Wor-ism)

does it not serve as one in a sense though, by buying goods that is currently in shortage

No. Cash reserves are mostly useful for expanding the building.

It's a lot cheaper to expand a building with a strong cash reserve

You might also be able to use the investment pool as well depending on your laws

@Skellius9(An-Staf-Wor-ism)

this is a throughput penalty right?

Worse, it's an output penalty iirc

@Skellius9(An-Staf-Wor-ism)

OOF, but that would mean you make less stuff for the same amount the input

You also just can't buy the inputs you need

Basically if you have input goods shortages your building is temporarily ruined and you should fix it ASAP

@Trinexx (CK Community)

please don't import arguments from outside the server

But I have an input goods shortage in my drama factory

Abandon spheres of influence. Embrace customs union cubes.

All the micro in V3 is economic

Discussions of what is and isn't "mana" aren't very interesting or productive imo

@Lain of the Wired - May Faction

AAR : Canada - Pt.1 - by Daniel "neondt" Tolman

CONFEDERATED CANADA starts here. Goals for this playthrough: - Unite Canada - Have a railway connect the Atlantic and Pacific oceans - Pass the Multiculturalism law - Pass Public Health Insurance and have maximum investment in Healthcare - Remain a British subject

We're playing as Upper Canada, which would historically become the province of Ontario

We only have a single state, and it's not at all developed. Just a few farms, plus a coal mine and a sulphur mine.

Our tech is pretty damn good though, especially our Society tech. Often I'd be tempted to go straight for Railways, but the natural infrastructure of the region means we won't need that for quite a long time. Instead I'll beeline Nationalism.

I've kicked out the ruling Landowners, who have most of the country's political clout. I'm sure this will be fine. They're replaced with the only slightly relevant Industrialists and Intelligentsia. I'm going to do my best to industrialize and liberalize the country.

Right now, the law that serves my interests the most without risking a revolution is Poor Laws. This will provide a small amount of welfare while empowering the Industrialists.

We start out with Religious Schools. Eventually I'll want to switch them to Public Schools but for now this is fine. I'm immediately going to start expanding them. This will empower the Devout, which I'm not big fan of, but they're also not likely to oppose me either.

On to the national budget. I am very pleased to discover that we have Payroll Tax, an actual real tax law that doesn't rely on having millions of peasants. Most of the money goes towards maintaining the military. I'm not interested in war this session, so I'm just going to disband everything. This will drastically reduce both our expenses and the power of the Armed Forces.

We're part of the British Market and we intend to remain there. This means we'll need to pay attention to market trends that we largely do not control and react to them.

One thing I immediately notice is the high price of Artillery. We may not need our own military force but we can certainly sell arms to our overlords.

So I'm starting out by creating an Arms Industry

Given that we're a OPM, another thing to keep in mind is that every building in the country has a significant impact on the balance of power. A single building that employs Capitalists will shift wealth and power to the Industrialists with far more impact than it would in a larger country, for example.

My now completed Arms Industries employ Engineers, Machinists, Laborers, and Shopkeepers

These Arms Industries are owned by the Merchant Guilds, which increases the employment of Shopkeepers in the building

When we have the Rifling technology we'll be able to switch o private ownership, which will employ more Capitalists.

@Captain "Power BI" Nemo

Which IGs do your Shopkeepers tend to support?

Petite Bourgeoisie

Daniel "neondt" Tolman

Petite Bourgeoisie

Who I have no use for and may become very dangerous in the future. They're reactionary conservatives.

Now that my Arms Industries are fully employed I can see that they're making a tidy profit and enriching the people who work there. The price of Iron is causing input costs to be high, but thankfully the price of Cannons is even higher resulting in a profitable business.

@Lion - (Political) Party Pooper

How are the Landed Gentry taking getting booted out of government? Do you have a load of radicals now?

They were not thrilled, but they're not going to try to overthrow the government

I'm also seeing that Coal has become expensive in the British Market, so that's my next industry to expand.

@TotallyJazzed

So what's the plan for confederation? Get Big Boy Britain to back you in all your plays?

If all goes to plan I won't even need to start any plays

Because I'm using Atmospheric Engines in my Coal Mines, I'm able to activate the Private Ownership PM which employs Capitalists. I'm trying to shift wealth and power away from the Landowners any way I can.

So expanding my Coal Mines will not only increase my GDP and SoL, it will shift my internal politics in the direction I want.

Relations with Britain btw are very poor for historical reasons. We're working on improving them. We're also improving relations with our fellow Canadians

@veluum

What's your current SoL btw

Very average

We're using the slowest construction method so building things takes a while, but it's also cheap. We basically break even in budgetary terms while we're constructing in Ontario

@Lion - (Political) Party Pooper

What are the accepted cultures of Upper Canada?

Anglo-Canadian

Daniel "neondt" Tolman

Anglo-Canadian

With our Racial Segregation laws, we will accept any culture with European heritage

This unfortunately means that we discriminate against the Native American peoples whose land we live on. We'll try to address that later on.

@Glenmordor

Can we use the sulfur to make any more valuable goods at the moment?

Not right now. But in the future I think we're likely to build some Chemical Plants

Coal continues to be expensive, so for now I'm just going to continue expanding my Coal Mines

Both the Industrialists and Intelligentsia are very happy with our government. The Industrialists are causing Capitalists to increase their contribution to the Investment Pool.

And with my Mercantilism law I can use the Investment Pool on almost anything that will generate profit.

Oh and the Intelligentsia are increasing my Migration Attraction.

I have plenty of Authority that I'm doing nothing with. I'll enact a Decree to increase the throughput of my mines.

@L.L.

Who wants to migrate into Canada at the moment?

Mostly other Canadians

Literacy is over 50% and rising. We're continuing to invest in Religious Schools

Due to my excessive micromanagement of the coal industry, our coal mines are the most productive in the world in terms of productivity per employee

Though certainly not in terms of raw output

@Staffordist Canadian

Could you start attracting perhaps the Irish, take advantage of the future potato famine?

We've already attracted about 600 Irish to Ontario!

It's October 1837

The budget is looking REALLY good now. I'm going to try increasing construction speed.

Increasing construction speed creates a deficit, but we have plenty of gold reserves for now. I think I'll keep myself in deficit to grow my early economy.

Our GDP is a little higher than Lower Canada's. I need to be the largest Canadian economy for reasons.

@Glenmordor

How much has GDP increased since the start of the game?

It's almost doubled. This is because I started with essentially no productive industry, and now I have insanely productive coal mines. This seems like a big increase, but in the same way that double 1 is 2.

@L.L.

There are some law you want to enact in the short term?

Poor Laws. Increase SoL very slightly, empowers the Industrialists.

I'm actually going to spend all of my Authority. This means I get no bonus to law enactment time at all. I'll be spending it on a Decree that increases my Migration Attraction even further. This is important because my population is low, and that could be a hard blocker on economic expansion.

For now, our low population means low bureaucracy cost for institutions. Our religious schools are so cheap to maintain that I don't even need a single government administration building.

@Captain "Power BI" Nemo

Because of the reforms Daniel has already taken, the impetus for the rebellions is already dead in the water

I actually put the Radicals in power

GDP has reached £1 million

@tonymarinov

What’s your population currently?

400k people live in Upper Canada

@jo3ski

How much are you limited by resource levels in Ontario? If I remember correctly resource levels are capped and I can’t think of too much coal around Ontario ( though I could be wrong)

We're very limited. Our coal mines are doing a lot of work for us now but we only have capacity for 11 in the state.

Ontario has the following natural resources, all at about the same capacity: coal, sulfur, wood. It has only 26 arable land, which I can use for livstock, wheat farms, and tobacco.

@Glenmordor

Can later tech increase the potential number of mines available?

No but it can help me get a lot more out of the mines I have

@Purestorm

11 is considered low?

Prussia's part of the Rhineland has 23

US-Mexican war has kicked off. USA wants Utah and New Mexico

We just got railway tech through tech spread. Cool, but not useful right now.

Industrialists now have 22% of the total political clout

@Quantum Menace

I'm hoping we can avoid that.

@gameing

Daniel "neondt" Tolman

That's enough to staff 2 coal mines!

@Quantum Menace

Rural Folk are actually the most influential, due to our fairly liberal voting franchise and the number of people still not employed in industry.

@Glenmordor

We're now making a profit using our best available construction method

Ontario is at this point basically just a coal mine

That said nobody is obscenely wealthy. Capitalists are certainly profiting but the wealth gap is much lower than I saw in e.g. my Papal game

OCR: Affluent (36.0)

@Lion - (Political) Party Pooper

How's that Arms Industry doing?

It's doing alright. The price of artillery isn't as high as it was when I built it, but it's still profitable and contributing to my GDP

@Stresemannite

I'm fine with USA getting Oregon, so long as British Columbia remains Canadian

We actually managed to pass Poor Laws. Since opposing IG's are still pretty strong, there's no much we can do without massive opposition. One law that nobody objects to is Private Health Insurance. We'll eventually want Public Health Insurance but this will at least allow us to expand the institution.

With all these institutions I'm eventually going to need to expand the Bureaucracy

With the growing population and already quite a few institutions to fund, I'm only just above 0 right now

@Glenmordor

How much urbanisation will we get if we build some government offices?

+20

More than most buildings

I've started building a Government Administration. I can really see the impact of the Investment Fund on the national budget. Building Coal Mines is much cheaper because Capitalists are very eager to invest

@daevious

Is it possible to see who's buying our coal?

We're just throwing it into the British Market. There's a map mode to see which states in the market are consuming coal, but not gonna show you that

I can tell you that it's mostly the north of England

Ontario is actually the largest producer of Coal in the market

@Purestorm

There's a state-by-state breakdown. Yorkshire is the single biggest consumer

We produce 500 coal vs Lancashire's 300 (edited)

@Glenmordor

We just had an election (won't talk details) and the Industrialists came out on top. Their leader, Charles Beckwith, is now the Governor of the colony

GDP has now tripled since game start

@pocketskittles

Returning to expansion of coal mines. Taking a short break from that allowed cash reserves to build up, making construction costs even cheaper

@Trinexx (CK Community)

No, but I'll probably volunteer

I think I got more coal in Ontario after annexing HBC. Because Ontario was a split state and HBC owned some of the more rural parts of the state region

@Laurin

i wonder if there is ever a reason to not just max your resource buildings

Many reasons. Besides what Kadaeux said, its not always profitable to just spam raw materials.

In Ontario I had a lot of capacity for Sulfur Mines and I barely used any of it. There just wasn't enough demand to bother fully exploiting it.

@Laurin

but let's say it's 1880 and you're not really lacking the necessary pops or money<, profitability is just not quite there, does it hurt to have a higher capacity than is currently in use?

Sometimes it's definitely beneficial to produce more than you need - if you have other industries that use those materials and which are more important to you then it might be worth sacrificing the profitability of your raw materials industries. But if you're not personally profiting from manufactured goods (e.g. Ontario wasn't doing much with Coal) then that's not worthwhile.

@Kadaeux

Dont upgraded/expanded buildings have higher maintenance of some kind?

They require more inputs and employment. So you need to gauge what the right level of expansion is for your market conditions and goals

More isn't inherently better

@Harry Hinderson

Tell that to Norway Venezuela Saudi Arabia Iran Libya Texas Iraq Kuwait Russia the UAE

Demand for oil in 2022 is extremely high

The next dev diary will be in the future

Maps are shown at my discretion and I did not feel benevolent today. It's not yet time for videos/streams.

@Holy Doggo

every game is built for the developers before the players, we are the secondary market - the developers are the primary market (last shitpost from me lol)

This is honestly not completely wrong. I make stuff that I would want to play.

We tend to work a bit of overtime on release days, and then compensate by taking time off another day. Main reason is to identify and fix critical issues as they're discovered.

@Trinexx (CK Community)

how many projects have you worked on for PDS by this point? Just out of curiosity

This is my third. Worked a bunch on EU4. A tiny bit on Imperator. Been on V3 since September-ish of 2020. V3 is the first project where I'm officially on the leads team but was de facto doing it for most of my EU4 time.

Daniel "neondt" Tolman

This is my third. Worked a bunch on EU4. A tiny bit on Imperator. Been on V3 since September-ish of 2020. V3 is the first project where I'm officially on the leads team but was de facto doing it for most of my EU4 time.

On EU4 I was de facto content design lead. Most mission trees are my designs. Also did a bunch of feature design too. Pirates and Hussites for example. Pretty much the whole Manchu patch was my design as well. Very proud of China rework.

IG leader can have various ideologies, but IG's fundamentally represent certain things. Intelligentsia are social liberals, PB are reactionaries, for example.

Trade Unions always advocate for working class interests, but they might not be communists

@Alex "Alex" Hesseborn

This

@Bioiron

so wait is there only one primary culture?

Depends on what country you're playing. But you don't ever get more than you start with except by forming a country.

Russia only has Russian primary culture.

@TotallyJazzed

@Lion - (Political) Party Pooper

That's correct

Cultures have traits, rather than groups

@Lloyien

Cultures can have multiple traits, then?

Yes

Every culture has at least 2

@Lloyien

What's the other trait for Bengali?

I think it's Indo-Aryan Language or something like that. Indian cultures are split between that and Dravidian.

@Lloyien

So there's always a geographic/racial and a linguistic trait? So Franco-Canadian would also have the Francophone trait?

There's not always a linguistic trait, but often there is. Traits are added for the sake of creating plausible gameplay scenarios. For this reason Irish culture specifically does not have the Anglophone trait.

@Lloyien

Would it be possible to build an event chain to incorporate Ireland into the Anglophone world by giving Irish the Anglophone trait if Britain and Ireland meet certain prerequisites?

I have a feeling that cultures are static and cannot be modified in-game, but I am not 100% sure

Pretty sure it is not moddable

@Ulf "UlfDerDritte" III

Yeah that's do-able

@tyrone

People who would be discriminated in your country aren't very likely to immigrate to it

@Nils

as it should be A big common market is a good idea but if your nation is rather dismal you will loose to your partners Hello EEC

Yep. Joining a customs union just to leech off a more developed market might see all of your pops deciding they'd rather live in those more developed states (edited)

@Doodlez - Fotp

If my nation doesnt allow migration how does that interact with a shared market?

Closing your borders is a solution to the above scenario. If you close your borders your pops can't leave

Korea begins with closed borders, so if it joins the Chinese Market there won't be any migration between those countries

@Lloyien

If you close your borders, can you trade with the outside world?

You can still trade, it's not the same as economic isolationism

@Lion - (Political) Party Pooper

It is not. Rural folk and PB tend to like it though

@Dan

That's a very broad question and I'm not sure I can give a concise answer. If there's any aspect of the game in particular you'd like to ask about I can try to give a more targeted answer.

@Russ Kaunelainen

Yes, some countries have multiple primary cultures. USA has Yankee and Dixie. GB has English and Scottish.

I think it should be possible for countries to achieve GP status through art spam. Some factors made it easier than I'd expect from the released game however, such as the instability of the other GP's and the AI's reluctance to build their own Arts Academies.

@Arctem | Horse Mod

This is true. The experience of playing larger nations is very different from playing smaller nations. I think people got a glimpse of that in my short Russia game.

@tyrone

@HP L1908w

@gameing

Most definitely. I'd expect to have Austria opposing my plays against Sardinia and Sicily - and indeed for those two to work together more effectively.

I would also have likely needed to confront Austria directly, as they were forced to release both Lombardy and Venice due to devastating military defeats

@tyrone

what do market leaders get as benefits btw

They get to determine who can join the market, or kick people out. There are also trade benefits.

@tyrone

why would someone want to kick people out of a market?

Maybe they're undercutting an industry I rely on. Maybe I want to attack them later and I don't want them benefiting from my market access. Maybe they're consuming goods that I need for myself.

@Mr.Erik

maybe they are getting too much migration from my country

That too

@Solid Scrooge

Yes. GP France joined my market as GP Pope

@wes

All Popes will be Italian due to how ruler logic works

@HP L1908w

There is not

@HP L1908w

In V3 this is literally true

@wes

Is adding wargoals during a war possible?

No, all wargoals are determined during the diplomatic play stage

None

AAR : Canada - Pt.2 - by Daniel "neondt" Tolman

CONFEDERATED CANADA resumes here

Quick recap: last time we played as Upper Canada. We confederated with Quebec and the HBC, leaving us geographically large. We made a lot of money from coal, but the market is no longer as hungry for black gold as it once was and we've had to start diversifying - explosives seems to be a promising industry.

Incorporating the HBC has left us in a bit of a mess. We have a bureaucracy shortage, and the budget is in an extreme deficit. I'll need to investigate the and address the causes.

Looks like there's a university in Saskatchewan. As cool as this this I don't think we can really support that right now. Shutting it down.

We also really do not need naval bases

Although our bureaucracy shortage is small it results in more than 10% tax waste. We need to address this ASAP

@Aldeéra

Yes close the university, send the children to the coal mines

On the topic of coal mines, we actually have more capacity for them now in Ontario. Ontario was a split state, with the other part being owned by the HBC. We can now expand up to level 18 in Ontario.

Likewise we also have more capacity for Iron in Quebec

Removing expensive buildings has mostly solved the budgetary crisis, but I've also had to reduce government wages to normal levels. Many of the luxuries of playing OPM Ontario are no longer viable, as we have a larger and poorer population to deal with.

One new positive thing: the trade unions are becoming ever more relevant, and they approve of our government (though they're not part of it). Their approval gives us 10% throughput in our manufacturing industries

@Jüstinyen

yeah what particular reasons make the trade unions like the government right now?

They like our set of laws, such as our republican form of government and the right of assembly

Our population is now at 2 million, with GDP rising to almost £8 million

Due to discrimination against the First Nations, Nunavut and Manitoba have issues with Turmoil.

We ought to address this. Thankfully I'm already in the process of researching Egalitarianism to unlock more progressive laws.

@Jüstinyen

maybe getting rid of the police was a bad idea

In this playthrough I am aiming for a lighter touch. They're angry for good reason.

@The_Last.Satrap

How many Irish and how many French ?

132k Irish! The Irish population has grown dramatically, they're the 4th largest ethnic group in the country

We also have over 100k Finns

@steam train

Wow, any reasons in particular for the immigration spike?

We've been encouraging immigration to Ontario for the whole game. With its very high standard of living, it is the most attractive state in the British Market

There's something making the turmoil worse. The Petite Bourgeoisie despises our government's policies, and their Xenophobia has been activated. This increases the number of radicals from discrimination.

SoL in Ontario remains very high, but it's been on the decline since the end of the coal boom

OCR: Middling (16.5)

@mossos

Which pops support the PB

Shopkeepers mainly

And Clerks

@prequel memer

Out of the 2 million, how many are native people?

About 200k, 10% of the population

@The_Last.Satrap

Reeducate them.

No

The Bureaucracy shortage is over, but with our expanding institutions, growing population, and need to build quickly we need more than an absence of a deficit. Building more administrations to give us a healthy surpluss

And with the budgetary crisis largely resolved I'm resuming the expansion of coal mines in Ontario, as well as the Logging Camps in Quebec

Oh I should also check out the potentials of my new states

Manitoba mostly has wood. Nothing special here.

Nunavut is... Nunavut

Northwest Territories have a bit of iron

Saskatchewan already has some food industries and a logging camp. I'm actually expanding government administration here as well. It also has the potential for 15 levels of coal mines

Saskatchewan is a fairly promising state

Alberta though... even better. More coal, more sulfur, more wood.

And finally the Yukon territory has a little wood and iron.

@CatalystNarco

can you have more than 15 lvls if do some research?

No, tech doesn't give you more levels. It unlocks PM's that can make your building much more efficient.

We're getting close to maxing out our healthcare institution investment. We need more bureaucracy to complete it though

Updating our PM's in the Food Industries we inherited. They're mildly profitable with Canneries and Sweeteners

We're also going to start using explosives in the iron mines. Price of iron is increasing

Blasting in the sulfur mines as well

The downside of these explosives is that it increases the Mortality of the people employed there. Mining is dangerous work.

We now have Egalitarianism

We've begun enacting Multiculturalism. The PB and Anglican Church absolutely hate this. They are threatening to start a revolution and overthrow the government. Despite being very angry, they are not actually very popular. I don't think they'll be able to pull it off.

I'm going to research Pharmaceuticals next. A lot of people work in the mines so a reduction to Mortality seems valuable

@Jüstinyen

do you have an army to deal with at least the internal problems?

I do not.

@Umbrellaworker

How is the usa

Stable

Even more Irish!

OCR: Irish Migration Large numbcrs of Irish pcople have bcgun migrating to our state of Qucbcc and its surrounding statcs.

The governor of the colony is William Lyon Mackenzie. Apparently a famous figure in Canadian history. (edited)

I'm kicking the Industrialists out of the government. They've served their purpose but we don't need them any more

The Intelligentsia's Radical Party rules alone

The population is growing at an alarming rate. I'm really struggling to keep up with the bureaucracy costs. I might have to scale back on institutions. For now I'm taking on more deficit to build administrations in Alberta and Saskatchewan

Due to massive amounts of migration to Canada, the population is approaching 3 million

@Cara

Do you still have Decrees up?

I do actually

I could cancel the migration Decree, but the migration isn't just affecting Ontario any more

@tyrone

GDP just reached £10 million

Daniel "neondt" Tolman

@Jüstinyen

The boilers require extra coal, labour, and tools

Also this helps

None

AAR : Canada - Intermission - by Daniel "neondt" Tolman

I continued my Canada game for a while outside of the AAR format. In case people are interested, here's a summary of how things progressed. I faced two main obstacles. First was that the Industrialists I had spent most of the game building up are now my greatest opponents. Now that I want to start passing social democratic reforms, they oppose rather than support my laws. This became a problem when the labour movement kicked off and threatened a general strike if I didn't reform my Poor Laws into Wage Controls within a given period of time. Attempting to do this caused the Industrialists to threaten a revolution I wouldn't have been able to avoid. I just barely had time to pass Guaranteed Liberties (which lessens the risk of revolt if you invest in it sufficiently) and appease the Industrialists and then pass Wage Controls before the strike broke out. Now I have a powerful and angry Industrialist faction.

Second obstacle was economic. I really wanted to get my Hydroelectric Power Plants up and running, and to use start using electricity in some of my industries to increase their output. I especially wanted to use it in my Chemical Plants to increase the output of Explosives, which were nearing on a market shortage. Ontario actually has a state bonus to electricity generation due to Niagara Falls, and I was able to build quite a lot of power plants. Unfortunately my output was affected greatly by the labour strike, and my membership in the British Market came back to bite me. Mostly I've been producing raw and manufactured goods that British pops and buildings want to buy but which I have little use for within Canada. Electricity (at least in the current implementation) is just another market good, so all that I produced was available to the whole market immediately. This meant that I couldn't use it without creating a shortage, as Britain was using it all to refrigerate fish.

Yeah I do admit that the way electricity currently works is quite odd (edited)

@TreeGuy

Also what year was it by the end of your session?

Mid 1850's I think

Oh I also researched feminism. I got an event where I could appease the industrialists by having the trade union leader resign. The new leader was a feminist who will support Women's Suffrage. That'll probably be my next law. Only irrelevant IG's will even oppose it

Not sure it would work as a capacity

Capacities work best as slightly abstract things rather than tangible material outputs

I kinda liked the infrastructure idea

@lawsome

Would passing a law they like satisfy the Industrialists or do they make their evaluations of the government based on the laws as a whole, rather than whatever happened most recently?

Passing a law the industrialists like would have appeased them, but I didn't want to pass any of those laws

It's possible for a more populist feminist movement to happen but I'll likely pass Suffrage well before the triggers for that become valid

@TreeGuy

Is there a possibility that you continue the save in an aar format?

It's possible

For dinner today I have a full english breakfast. I really love mushrooms.

@Yagami913

What is the problem with electricity as good? Thats how modern grids work. Power plants selling and electricity companies buying, often from other countries if infrastructure allows it.

It's just a little odd that my hydroelectric plants in Ontario are being used to power fisheries in Ireland

Regardless of the oddities with electricity specifically, the situation does highlight one of the downsides of being part of a large market. Everyone has access to all the goods, so you can't just produce something and expect to have control over what happens to it.

My power plants were EXTREMELY profitable at least

Getting a head start on a brand new industry has a lot of benefits

@Viligans

Could you keep expanding them to increase the supply and stabilize the price? I'm guessing that any new jobs in those power plants are going to be pretty juicy given the profit margin.

Absolutely. And that's the plan. But I've been hampered by the strikes, and I only resolved that situation near the end of my play session.

My power plants are also just not very efficient. Although you can build them with a tier 3 tech, they only really start outputting a lot of electricity with a tier 4 tech that adds coal as the primary input (edited)

And I'm a long way from being able to comfortably get tier 4 techs

@Viligans

Luckily you have a local coal market with supply?

Indeed. I am the largest coal producer in the world now - I've maxed out every coal mine possible in Canada, using the most productive PM's I have available (which also helps with the price of explosives, making my chemical plants more profitable)

I think my current research is Dynamite, which will make my mines even more productive. Though I won't actually need to use that for a while. I produce so much coal that it's not especially expensive any more. Coal mines are still profitable and a huge contributor to my GDP, but they don't instantly enrich everyone who works there any more.

@Skellius9(An-Staf-Wor-ism)

at this point, would rolling back on coal PMs be a good idea seeing as the market is no longer as coal hungry

I don't think so. Rolling back to older PM's would make my chemical plants less profitable.

@lawsome

Are you at market share size where you can reliably raise profits by just constraining the output?

Yes but as I said I think there are more downsides than benefits to that

There are definitely situations where you might want to artificially limit supply though

I am a little worried about what will happen to my economy once oil starts being used.

I'm very reliant on coal

@Captain "Power BI" Nemo

Who currently controls Alaska?

Still Russia

There's not been a lot of major border changes, especially in the Americas

@Basil

Does Canada have oil deposits?

I think it has at least some? Not entirely sure

@Yagami913

Time to conquer texas

I think both USA and Mexico would have objections

also I still have no army

I'm suppressing internal revolts by making my society so free and democratic that pops prefer to use the established political process to voice concerns rather than taking to the streets

Daniel "neondt" Tolman

I'm suppressing internal revolts by making my society so free and democratic that pops prefer to use the established political process to voice concerns rather than taking to the streets

Those fools think that they can win elections and pass the reforms they like (edited)

@NEF

Maybe you could artificially increase the demand for coal by making more products that need coal such as steel?

I actually don't make Steel in Canada at all. I've never really investigated the viability of the industry in my market.

The collapse of the coal industry is a problem for future Daniel. And I hate that guy.

@lawsome

It does seem to undermine the "uncertain possibilities of elections" thing when the player can functionally prevent any law from passing except those that try outside-the-law means.

It's more that I know damn well that they're not going to win

The Mackenzie-union coalition is really strong

While the PB and Industrialists will not team up together to oppose me, at least for now

@NEF

You must protect our most profitable industry! What if it collapses and the people revolt due to lost SoL?

Let them eat coal

@Aquos

can't you restrict the export of goods outside of your country? or does that just doesn't matter because you are a subject and in Britains market?

Yeah my membership in the British Market prevents me from having that control

@The_Last.Satrap

Are we collapsing into liberal disasters like vic2 ?

The liberals are the government so no

For now anyway. I'll probably kick Mackenzie out eventually and have a purely Trade Union government

But for now his IG is increasing our legitimacy even though he has no strong feelings one way or the other about the laws we're passing now

@Rookie

In this timeline, would Karl Marx be Canadian?

No, we were not the first to discover Socialism

@Dr.Mundo

so Canada is authoritarianism now?

Not at all. We're extremely progressive.

The more progressive we get the less authority we generate. I can barely even pass a single Decree now.

@The_Last.Satrap

People who fail to catch-up with the progress are supressed I assume

Nobody is suppressed actually. People are free to advocate for whatever ideas they like. It's just that with so many people able to vote (hopefully including women soon), very few people are listening to dumb ideas like feudalism or racism.

More suffrage basically empowers the lower strata. Laborers typically don't care about politics, but with the franchise extended and literacy increasing, they're joining the Unions in droves.

Daniel "neondt" Tolman

More suffrage basically empowers the lower strata. Laborers typically don't care about politics, but with the franchise extended and literacy increasing, they're joining the Unions in droves.

The Unions have also been empowered by the fact that I caved in to all of their demands during strike negotiations. They're very popular and very successful.

@The_Last.Satrap

Please don't go stalinistic

Definitely not doing Stalinism in this run. Maybe council communism, who knows

Bioiron

given that the trade unions seemed to be largely powered by immigrant pops, do they have any desire for migration control at all?

Only the PB care about migration control. They're definitely a very relevant IG, but it's one of the reasons they don't get along with the Industrialists who really like the influx of cheap labour (edited)

I will say that's it's incredibly difficult to transition to communism peacefully. Council Republic is opposed by most IG's.

@The_Last.Satrap

Britain doesn't care to manipulate my internal politics. I can go communist and they won't do anything but grumble

@Aquos

For now I can't even pass the law. The labour movement wants labour rights rather than the abolition of capitalism atm

We know what socialism is but the Unions have yet to adopt it

Oh that reminds me. The Poor Laws were giving the Industrialists 30% more political power due to my high investment in it. Replacing it with Wage Controls has entirely removed that extra power.

The law also means that there is a national minimum wage

Don't remember. Mid-late 1850's

@Ads21
